ARTICLE XII. - SIGNAGE IN OLD TOWN 
 
Sec. 9.5-200. - Definitions 
For the purpose of this article, the following words shall have the following definitions ascribed to them, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
Animated. Having a rapid display of a sequence of images to create the illusion of movement. 
Balloon. Any object filled with air or gas placed to draw attention to a business, product, service, or premises, regardless of whether or not it contains an advertised message. 
Change of copy. The changing of letters, numbers, or figures on an integrated changeable display (e.g., marquees, gas prices, chalkboards, or whiteboards). 
Corner lot. A lot which has the entire length of at least two adjacent sides abutting a public street or right-of-way, provided the interior angle at the intersection is less than 135 degrees. 
Display surface. The surface upon which a sign or message is presented including borders, frames, and other similar features. The display surface does not include structural elements. 
Exterior wall. The exterior boundaries of a building that has a slope of 60 degrees or greater with the horizontal plane. 
Flag. A piece of fabric, cloth, plastic, vinyl, canvas, leather, or other similar material attached to a flagpole on one end used as a symbol of a nation, state, city, or other local government entity. Flags shall not include corporate logos. 
Flagpole. A staff or pole designed specifically to fly a flag. Cell towers, antennas, monopoles, or similar structures not primarily designed for use as a flagpole shall not be allowed as such. 
Indirect lighting. A source of external illumination not connected to the sign itself. 
Internal-indirect lighting. A source of illumination entirely within the sign (generally a freestanding letter) which makes the sign visible at night by means of lighting the background upon which the freestanding character is mounted. 
Internal lighting. A source of illumination within a sign that makes its contents visible at night by means of a translucent or transparent material, but wherein the source of the illumination is not visible. 
Letter of design approval. A written document granting permission by the Old Town Design Review Committee to complete specific improvements within the Old Town District. 
Logo. A design, insignia, or other marking used to identify a company, business, or product. 
Neon (electrical discharge tubing). A source of external illumination composed of tubing filled with an inert gas that emits light when exposed to an electrical charge located on a noncombustible surface. 
Notice. Notice required by this article shall be sufficient if it is affected by personal delivery, electronic mail, registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, or depositing the notice in the United States mail. 
Old Town Center District. The Old Town Center District is designated as listed in the Old Town Development Ordinance, Chapter 9.5 of the Lewisville Code of Ordinances, Appendix 1, but generally defined as the area bounded by Church, Charles, Elm, and Kealy Streets. 
Old Town Design District. The Old Town Design District is defined as listed in the Old Town Development Ordinance, Chapter 9.5 of the Lewisville Code of Ordinances, Appendix 1, but generally defined as the area bounded by College Street, Railroad Street, Purnell Street, South Edna Avenue, West Main Street and Degan Avenue. 
Old Town Design Review Committee (OTDRC). The Old Town Design Review Committee is defined as listed in the Old Town Development Ordinance, Chapter 9.5 of the Lewisville Code of Ordinances. 
Old Town District. The Old Town District shall include both the Old Town Center District and the Old Town Design District. 
Pennant. Any device made of cloth, canvas, plastic, foil, or any flexible material that moves or is designed to move freely in the wind, with or without a frame or other supporting structure, used for the purpose of advertising or drawing attention to a business, commodity, service, sale, or product. 
Premises. The area of real property designated as a lot on a final plat approved by the city and filed with the county clerk's office or an unplatted tract of land as shown on an abstract. 
Primary facade. The side of a building facing the street from which it draws its address, except as modified by written request from the property owner and approved by the city. 
Searchlight. Any apparatus capable of projecting a beam or beams of light. 
Secondary facade. Any side of a building not facing the street from which it draws its address, or which has been designated as the primary facade. 
Sign. A name, identification, description, display, or illustration which is affixed to, or represented directly or indirectly upon, a building, structure, or piece of land and which directs attention to an object, product, place, activity, institution, or business, or any medium, including its structure and component parts, which is used to attract attention to the subject matter for advertising purposes. 
•  Abandoned sign. A sign that: (1) fails to display any written or visual message on its display surface; (2) previously had a permit, but the permit has been expired for 30 or more consecutive days; (3) fails to identify or advertise a currently existing or operating business, lessor, service, owner, or product; or (4) only identifies or advertises an event or activity that has already occurred. A legal nonconforming sign, however, shall only be deemed abandoned if any of these conditions have been met for a consecutive 180-day period of time. 
•  Audible sign. Any sign that emits music, talking, words, or other sound or amplification. 
•  Awning, canopy, and/or marquee sign. A sign that is mounted on or integral to an awning, canopy, or marquee. 
•  Balloon sign. Any object filled with air or gas containing a message designed to advertise a product or premises. 
•  Banner sign. A flexible material such as cloth, paper, or vinyl on which a sign is painted or printed, intended for temporary purposes. 
•  Bench sign. A sign affixed to or painted on a bench located in or visible from a public right-of-way. 
•  Billboard. See "Off-Premises Sign." 
•  Building markers or historic designation tablets. Tablets approved by a governmental entity, address stones, building naming stones, or foundation stones typically indicating date of construction, architect, or founders. 
•  Business park entry sign. A sign meeting the requirements for low profile/monument signage that may be located on a common lot and represents the name of the development. 
•  Commercial real estate sign. A sign that advertises the sale, lease, financing, development, transfer, rental, or exchange of commercial property. 
•  Construction sign. A temporary sign erected on the premises where construction is taking place, during the period of such construction, indicating the names and/or contact information for the architects, engineers, landscape architects, contractors or similar design professionals, and the owners, financial supporters, sponsors, and similar individuals or firms having a role or interest with respect to the project. 
•  Customary identification sign. A sign indicating the name, type of business, hours of operation, and/or similar identification information. 
•  Directional sign. A sign limited to directional messages, principally for pedestrian or vehicular traffic, located at a property's point on ingress or egress. 
•  Electric/electrical sign. Any sign containing electrical wiring and internal illumination, but not including signs illuminated solely by an exterior light source. 
•  Feather flag. A sign designed to move freely that is attached to a pole or staff driven into the ground for support. 
•  Flashing sign. A blinking, scrolling, or animated sign, or a sign with intermittent or varying intensity of illumination or color, whether deliberate or as a consequence of a defect in the sign or the illumination source. 
•  Freestanding sign. A sign wholly unattached to a building or structure, and supported by its own internal or external structural members. 
•  Garage sale sign. A sign used to advertise a garage sale, yard sale, estate sale, or any other event defined under "occasional sales" pursuant to Chapter 7, Article VI, of the Lewisville City Code at an occupied residential property. 
•  Governmental sign. A sign installed, erected, maintained, or endorsed by a municipal, state, or federal governmental body for the purpose of public instruction regarding health, safety, or welfare, street or highway designation, or control of traffic. 
•  Grand opening sign. A commemoration that promotes the opening of a new business with balloons, balloon signs, inflatable signs, pendants, and/or streamers. 
•  Hanging sign. A sign suspended under an awning, canopy, or marquee. 
•  Human sign. A sign held by or attached to a human being, on-site at a business location. A human sign includes a person dressed in costume for the purposes of advertising or otherwise drawing attention to an individual, business, commodity, service, activity, or product. Human signs do not include ideological or political signs. 
•  Ideological sign. A sign communicating a message or idea for noncommercial purposes that are not otherwise specifically addressed separately by this article (i.e., political signs are addressed separately and will be regulated as a political, rather than ideological sign). 
•  Inflatable sign. Any object, the structure of which holds its shape through the use of a continuous operation fan supplying ambient air to the structure. Inflatable signs may contain an advertised message. 
•  Kiosk sign. A freestanding structure located in the city right-of-way that features the city identification panel at the top and displays directional information as set forth in the current City of Lewisville Kiosk Sign Program and Agreement. 
•  Legal nonconforming sign. A sign that is not in conformance with current regulations, but which was legally established at a prior date at which time it was in conformance with the then applicable standards. A legal nonconforming sign may be continued subject to the provisions of this article. 
•  Low-profile sign. A freestanding sign typically directed toward slower moving vehicular traffic with poles or supports partly or completely revealed. 
•  Menu board sign. A sign erected in conjunction with a use that incorporates a drive-through or drive-in and is generally used to provide service, product, and/or pricing for patrons who remain in their vehicle. Menu boards may contain two-way audible communication. 
•  Model home sign. A freestanding sign located on the premises of a single-family or multifamily model home. 
•  Monument sign. A freestanding sign having a low profile that shall be solid from the ground up with concealed poles or supports. 
•  Multi-tenant wall sign. A wall sign displaying the name of a business located in a building containing multiple tenants that utilize a mutual entrance. 
•  Off-premises construction sign. A temporary sign erected off the premises where construction is taking place, during the period of such construction, indicating the names and/or contact information for the architects, engineers, landscape architects, contractors or similar design professionals, and the owners, financial supporters, sponsors, and similar individuals or firms having a role or interest with respect to the project. 
•  Off-premises sign. A sign that is not an on-premises sign. 
•  On-premises sign. A sign identifying, advertising, or otherwise directing attention to a business, person, organization, activity, event, place, service, or product when such sign is installed and maintained on the same premises where that business, person, organization, activity, event place, service, and/or product is principally located, manufactured, or sold. 
•  Political sign. A sign primarily pertaining to any national, state, county, or local election. 
•  Portable display sign. A sign that is fixed to a temporary display structure, with or without wheels, which is moved from location to location at periodic intervals. 
•  Prohibited sign. Any sign listed as a prohibited sign in this article, signs that do not comply with this or other applicable ordinances, and signs that are otherwise prohibited. Prohibited signs may only be allowed as approved by the city council through a variance or appeal process. 
•  Projecting sign. A sign that is wholly or partly dependent upon a building or wall for support and projects more than 12 inches from such building or wall, generally at a right angle. 
•  Property protection sign. A sign used to advise visitors of a policy in place by the property owner (e.g., "No Smoking", "No Soliciting") or to warn of potential dangers (e.g., "Beware of Dog", "High Voltage"). 
•  Residential real estate sign. A sign that advertises the sale, lease, financing, development, transfer, rental, or exchange of residential property. 
•  Restaurant menu case. A weather-tight device containing a copy of the regular menu for a restaurant, cafe, bar, or similar. Restaurant menu cases are accessory signs intended to be read from a pedestrian level. 
•  Roof sign. A sign located on or above a roof of a building or structure. 
•  Sandwich board sign. A sign of A-frame or similar design intended for placement in the pedestrian area in front of the business being advertised. 
•  Signs advertising illegal activities. A sign which advertises activities that are illegal under federal, state, or local law. 
•  Signs on public property or utility easements. Any sign, whether temporary or permanent, placed on public property or recorded utility easements including public rights-of-way. 
•  Signs required by law. A sign that is required for health, safety, welfare, accessibility, or other reason by national, state, or local codes or laws (e.g., fire lane delineations, maximum occupant load postings, accessible parking spaces). 
•  Single tenant wall sign. A wall sign utilized by a business that is the sole occupant of a building. 
•  Subdivision identity sign. A permanent sign, meeting the requirements for low-profile/monument signage, which may be located on a common lot and generally identifies a residential development and refers to the name of the subdivision. 
•  Sub-standard sign. Any sign with a missing, broken, bent, cracked, decayed, dented, harmful, hazardous, illegible, leaning, splintered, ripped, torn, twisted, or unsightly surface element, background, or support. 
•  Temporary sign. A sign that does not have a permanent foundation and is intended to be displayed for a limited period of time. 
•  Temporary window sign. An interchangeable promotional sign that is attached, painted, or placed in or on a building window intended to advertise a particular product or event for a limited time. 
•  Variable message electronic readerboard. A sign that utilizes alternating electronic data control components such as computer-generated messages or some other electronic means of changing copy. These signs include displays using incandescent lamps, LEDs, LCDs, or a flipper matrix. 
•  Vehicle sign. An advertising sign, trailer, or billboard that is attached to a motorized vehicle. 
•  Vertical pole banner sign. A sign located on a vertical light pole on a platted lot or public property that is not otherwise allowed as a freestanding sign and shall be limited to cloth, flexible plastic, vinyl, or similar material (i.e., no cardboard, wood, rigid plastics, etc.). 
•  Wall sign. A sign attached to or painted on a wall, parapet, or facade of a building or structure with the exposed face of the sign on a plane parallel to the plane of such wall. 
•  Window sign. A sign that is applied to the exterior or interior of a window or within three feet of the interior of the window. A window sign does not include merchandise or models of products or services incorporated in the window display. 
•  Zoning change sign. An official sign issued by the City indicating a pending zoning change. 
Sign area. The measurement of a sign's display surface. 
Sign plan. A scaled plan showing building and sign locations, dimensions, and similar information to ensure the proper placement of the sign (See "Permit requirements"). 
Sign structure. Any structure which supports, or is capable of supporting, a sign. A sign structure may or may not be an integral part of the building. 
Structure. That which is built or constructed, an edifice or building of any kind, or any configuration artificially built up or composed of parts joined together in some definite manner. 
Vehicle. Any device in, upon, or by which any person or property may be transported. 
(Ord. No. 3987-04-2013 , § 1(Exh. A), 4-1-13; 0032-18-ORD , § 4, 6-4-18)  
Sec. 9.5-201. - General requirements. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this article is to permit signs that will not by their size, location, and construction endanger the public health and safety of individuals, or confuse, mislead, or obstruct the vision necessary for traffic safety, or decrease the value of surrounding properties. Also, this article is intended to create a more aesthetically pleasing community for Old Town visitors and residents by preventing the over concentration and improper placement of signs and by requiring all signs to be properly maintained. 
The Old Town District contains the original downtown commercial center as well as the original residential neighborhoods that surround and support the area. In recent years, citizens and business leaders have come to recognize the historic, turn-of-the-century character of this community as unique in Lewisville and worthy of preserving and enhancing. Signs are integral to the overall character of the Old Town streetscape. 
(b)  Applicability. This article shall apply to all signs located within the Old Town District. For requirements not referenced in this article, the standards listed in Chapter 11, Signs, shall apply. 
Photographs and illustrations depicted in this article are intended to be used for representative purposes only, and may not be in compliance with all applicable provisions. 
 
Bank at corner of Main and Mill Street 
 
(c)  The Old Town Design Review Committee (OTDRC). In order to provide for the preservation and enhancement of the Old Town character, the city council created the OTDRC composed of Old Town business owners and residents. One of the duties the OTDRC is to review the design of new signs and the alteration, renovation, or rehabilitation of existing signs requiring a permit in order to preserve and enhance the Old Town character. 
(d)  Guidelines for signage in Old Town. The guidelines for signage in Old Town (Appendix A) apply to signs located within the Old Town District. The guidelines are intended to encourage the highest level of design quality and provide flexibility for creativity in sign design. The guidelines should be followed to the greatest extent possible. To that end, city staff and the OTDRC shall work with the sign owner to explore designs that maximize conformance with the guidelines. The OTDRC shall not deny a letter of design approval solely because a sign fails to comply with the guidelines. 
(e)  Compliance with other codes. All signs shall comply with any and all codes incorporated by reference or contained within the City of Lewisville Code of Ordinances. 
(f)  Consent of property owner. The city will not issue a sign permit to a person proposing to place a sign on property owned by another party unless that person provides the city with a written consent from the property owner or the property owner's authorized agent. 
(g)  Enforcement authority. The building official is hereby authorized and directed to enforce all the provisions of this article. 
(h)  Responsibility. All property owners, tenants, contractors, and/or representatives listed on the sign permit application shall be responsible for reproduction and installation of signage as specified by this article or approved by the OTDRC. 
(i)  Right of entry. Upon presentation of proper credentials, the building official may enter, at reasonable times, any building, structure, or premises in the city to perform any duty required by this article. 
(j)  Maintenance. All signs and sign structures together with their supports, braces, guys, and anchors shall be kept in good repair and in a proper state of preservation. The display surface of all signs shall be kept neatly painted or posted at all times. 
(k)  Weatherproofing. All signs shall be constructed so as to prevent the accumulation of rain water in or on the sign. 
(l)  Identification of manufacturer; installer. Each sign shall be identified by a label, nameplate, or trademark identifying the manufacturer and/or installer of the sign, except those signs that do not require the submittal of a sign plan. 
(m)  Sexually oriented businesses. Any sign advertising a sexually-oriented business, as defined by the City Code, shall conform to all the requirements of this article and shall not advertise, either graphically or verbally, by explicit or literal expression, connotation, or implied reference, any specified sexual activity or specified anatomical area. 
Because of the objectionable characteristics and a deleterious effect upon the quality of life in surrounding neighborhoods that a sexually oriented business may produce, the allowable square footage of such signs are limited to 150 square feet aggregate total per building. 
(n)  Legal nonconforming signs. 
(1)  A legal nonconforming sign shall not be enlarged, expanded, replaced, refaced, or otherwise modified. Ordinary repairs and maintenance of a legal nonconforming sign are allowed, but any repairs and/or maintenance that make structural alterations and/or otherwise extend the normal life of the legal nonconforming sign are strictly prohibited. 
(2)  A legal nonconforming sign whose structure or display surface is damaged or destroyed shall be made to comply with the requirements of this article or shall be removed. A sign is considered damaged or destroyed only if the cost of repairing the sign is more than 60 percent of the cost of erecting a new sign of the same type at the same location. 
(3)  If a legal nonconforming sign qualifies as an abandoned sign per this article, such sign shall be removed or otherwise made to comply with the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3987-04-2013 , § 1(Exh. A), 4-1-13)  
Sec. 9.5-202. - Permit requirements. 
(a)  Permit required. No sign other than those exceptions listed in this article shall be erected, reerected, constructed, altered, refaced, or maintained except as provided by this article and only after a permit for the same has been issued by the building inspection division of the community development department. A separate permit shall be required for each sign for a business entity and a separate permit shall be required for each group of signs on a single sign structure. In addition, electrical permits shall be obtained for illuminated and/or permanently wired signs. 
(b)  Information required with a permit application. Application for a permit required under this article shall be made upon forms furnished by the building inspection division of the community development department. Such application shall contain the location by street and number of the proposed sign structure, as well as the name and address of the sign owner and the sign contractor. The building official may require the filing of plans or other pertinent information where in his opinion such information is necessary to ensure compliance with this article. All signs shall require the submittal of a scaled sign plan showing the following information: 
(1)  Building locations, dimensions and elevations; 
(2)  Size, location, and type of both existing and proposed signs; 
(3)  Identification of the facade (primary or secondary) on which the sign is proposed; 
(4)  Nearest street intersections and driveway locations; 
(5)  Zoning designation; 
(6)  Name of applicant, sign owner, and sign constructor; 
(7)  Corner "clear vision areas", if applicable; 
(8)  Engineering data on signs and/or sign structures exceeding 20 feet in height or when required to ensure compliance with this article; and 
(9)  Any easements on the property. 
(c)  Time to review permit. The permit application for a sign permissible under this article shall be reviewed and notice of any deficiencies, approval, or denial given to the applicant by the building inspection division of the community development department within ten working days from the receipt of a complete application. Signs requiring a letter of design approval shall be scheduled for the next available regular meeting of the OTDRC upon receipt of a complete application from the building inspection division of the community development department. 
(d)  Letter of design approval. 
(1)  [Approval characteristics.] The OTDRC may approve applications for a letter of design approval and requests for modifications in one or more of the characteristics listed in Table 1.

(2)  Standards and limits of approval by OTDRC. 
a.  The OTDRC may approve an application for a letter of design approval if the intent of this article is served and the character of Old Town in enhanced. 
b.  The OTDRC shall not grant approval if the sign: 
1.  Is prohibited by, or conflicts with, the requirements specified in this article; 
2.  Is not allowed in the Old Town District; 
3.  Conflicts with the building code or other city ordinances; 
4.  May be injurious or detrimental to neighboring properties; or 
5.  May threaten the public health, safety or welfare. 
(3)  Signs not requiring a letter of design approval. The following signs do not require a letter of design approval but do require a permit and must comply with all the requirements of this article: 
a.  Temporary banner signs. 
b.  Commercial real estate signs. 
c.  Construction signs. 
d.  Kiosk signs (in compliance with the City of Lewisville Kiosk Sign Program and Agreement). 
(4)  Signs requiring approval by the city council. In the event an application for a letter of design approval is recommended for denial by city staff but approved by the OTDRC, the application shall require approval from the city council. 
(5)  Right to appeal a decision of the OTDRC. An applicant for a sign permit whose request is denied by the OTDRC may appeal such decision to the city council by submitting an appeal request to the building inspection division of the community development department within ten calendar days from the date of the denial notification. The decision of the city council is final and nonappealable. 
(e)  To whom issued. No permit for the erection of any sign, with the exception of banner and vertical pole banner signs, shall be issued to any person other than those licensed by the state and registered and insured in the city in accordance with this article. 
(f)  Prohibited locations. No permit shall be issued for a new or modified sign when an illegal sign exists on the premises unless the illegal sign is removed or brought into full compliance prior to permit issuance. 
(g)  Permit expiration. Any permit issued pursuant to this article shall become null and void if the work authorized is not commenced within 60 days from the date of issuance, or if the work is suspended or abandoned for a cumulative period of 120 days at any time after the work is commenced. A new permit shall be required for any project exceeding these timeframes. 
(h)  Suspension and revocation. The building official may, in writing, suspend or revoke a permit issued pursuant to this article whenever such permit is issued in error or issued on the basis of incorrect information or where the work is done in violation of any ordinance, regulation, or any provision of this article. 
(i)  Fees. The fees for sign permits shall be set forth in the Lewisville City Code, Article VIII, section 2-201. 
(Ord. No. 3987-04-2013 , § 1(Exh. A), 4-1-13)  
Sec. 9.5-203. - License requirements. 
(a)  License and registration required. No person shall install, erect, or maintain any sign requiring a permit until verification of a current state license and registration with the city as a contractor is submitted and approved by the building official. 
(b)  Expiration of registration. Any registration issued under the terms of this article shall expire 365 days after registration. 
(c)  Improper use of registration. It shall be unlawful for any registered sign contractor to allow his name or registration to be used by any other person, directly or indirectly, for the purpose of obtaining a permit or for performing work under such registration. 
(Ord. No. 3987-04-2013 , § 1(Exh. A), 4-1-13)  
Sec. 9.5-204. - Inspection requirements. 
All signs for which a permit is required shall be subject to inspection. 
(a)  Footing inspections may be required for all signs having footings. 
(b)  All signs containing electrical wiring shall be subject to the provisions of the governing electrical code, and the electrical components used shall bear the label of an approved testing agency. 
(c)  All signs may be reinspected at the discretion of the building official. 
(Ord. No. 3987-04-2013 , § 1(Exh. A), 4-1-13)  
Sec. 9.5-205. - Sign structure. 
(a)  Construction of sign supports. The supports for all signs or sign structures shall be placed in or upon private property, except as modified by this article, and shall be securely built, constructed, and erected in conformance with the requirements of this article. 
(b)  Anchoring. Uplift due to overturning shall be adequately resisted by proper anchorage to the ground or to the structural frame of a building. The weight of earth superimposed over footings may be used in determining the dead-load resisting moment. Such earth shall be carefully placed and thoroughly compacted. 
(1)  Signs attached to masonry, concrete, or steel shall be safely and securely fastened thereto by means of metal anchors, bolts, or approved expansion screws of sufficient size and anchorage to safely support the loads applied. 
(2)  No wooden blocks, plugs, or anchors with wood used in connection with screws or nails shall be considered proper anchorage, except in the case of signs attached to wood framing. 
(c)  Wind loads. Signs and sign structures shall be designed to resist wind forces as specified in the current city building code. Copies of all sections referenced herein will be furnished upon request to the building inspection division of the community development department. 
(1)  Vertical design loads except roof live loads shall be assumed to be acting simultaneously with the wind loads. 
(2)  For signs on buildings, the dead and lateral loads shall be transmitted through the structural frame of the building to the ground in such a manner as not to overstress any of the elements thereof. 
(3)  All bracing systems shall be designed and constructed to transfer lateral forces to the foundations. 
(4)  The overturning moment produced from the lateral forces shall in no case exceed two-thirds of the dead load resisting moment. 
(d)  Allowable stresses. 
(1)  The design of wood, concrete, steel, or aluminum members shall conform to the requirements of the current city building code. 
(2)  Loads, both vertical and horizontal, exerted on the soil shall not produce stresses exceeding those specified in the current city building code. 
(3)  The working stresses of wire rope and its fastenings shall not exceed 25 percent of the ultimate strength of the rope or fasteners. 
(4)  Working stresses for wind loads combined with dead loads may be increased as specified in the current city building code. 
(Ord. No. 3987-04-2013 , § 1(Exh. A), 4-1-13)  
Sec. 9.5-206. - Sign materials. 
(a)  General. 
(1)  Materials of construction for signs and sign structures shall, at a minimum, be of the quality and grade as specified for buildings in the current city building code. 
(2)  In all signs and sign structures the materials shall, in the absence of specified requirements, conform to the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Allowable sign materials. 
(1)  All permanent signs shall be made of metal, masonry, stone, wood, molded polyurethane, or glass approved by the OTDRC. 
(2)  All temporary signs shall be made of metal, masonry, wood, glass, or a flexible material such as cloth, paper, vinyl or other similar material. 
(3)  Lettering shall be made of painted, vinyl, engraved, or mounted letters. 
(4)  Structural steel shall be of such quality as to conform to the current city building code. Secondary members in contact with or directly supporting the display surface may be formed of light gauge steel provided such members are designed in accordance with the specifications of the design of light gauge steel as specified in the current city building code and shall be galvanized. Secondary members, when formed integrally with the display surface, shall be not less than 0.024 inch in thickness. When not formed integrally with the display surface, the minimum thickness of the secondary members shall be 0.10 inch. The minimum thickness of hot-rolled steel members furnishing structural support for signs shall be one-fourth inch, except that, if galvanized, such members shall be not less than one-eighth inch thick. Steel pipes shall be of such quality as to conform to the current city building code. 
(5)  Wood anchors and supports embedded in the soil shall be cedar or other naturally decay-resistant wood or pressure treated with an approved preservative and shall be marked or branded by an approved agency as such. 
(6)  Plastic is not an approved material for use in the Old Town District. 
(7)  Glass or other transparent panels in signs shall not exceed 12 square feet in any one section. 
(8)  Glass without coatings or tints shall be used for windows and doors of all ground floor retail buildings. Use of reflective glass or coverings to obscure transparency is not permitted. 
(c)  Restrictions on combustible materials. Low-profile/monument signs may be constructed of metal, masonry, wood, or cementitous fiberboard. Wall signs, projecting signs, and awning, canopy, and/or marquee signs shall be of noncombustible materials. 
Exceptions: 
(1)  No combustible materials shall be used in the construction of electric signs. 
(2)  Nonelectric wall signs may be constructed of combustible materials on walls allowed to be of unprotected combustible construction. 
(3)  Nonstructural trim may be composed of wood, metal, or any combination thereof. 
(4)  Signs attached to the surface of fabric awnings may be allowed when in conformance with the city building code. 
(5)  Signs erected within five feet of an exterior wall in which there are openings within the area of the sign shall be constructed of noncombustible material. 
(Ord. No. 3987-04-2013 , § 1(Exh. A), 4-1-13)  
Sec. 9.5-207. - Sign requirements. 
(a)  Color palette. Materials or paints that are extremely bright, fluorescent, or neon in color shall not be permitted; however, limited use of neon lighting on signs is allowed. Only historic colors certified by the National Trust for Historic Preservation and compatible with other colors on the building shall be allowed for use on signage. 
(b)  Illumination. The light from any source intended to illuminate a sign shall be shaded, shielded, or directed so that the light intensity or brightness shall not adversely affect surrounding uses or negatively impact safe vision of pedestrians or vehicle operators moving on public or private streets, driveways, or parking areas. 
Two types of artificial lighting for signs may be allowed in the Old Town District subject to review and approval by the Old Town Design Review Committee: 
(1)  Indirect lighting. Indirect lighting shall be directed at the sign and not produce glare or other atmospheric influence beyond the boundaries of the property. 
(2)  Neon lighting (electrical discharge tubing). Exposed neon lighting shall only be used as lettering or perimeter trim limited to no more than two charged tubes. 
(c)  Number of signs. The allowable number of signs for businesses in the Old Town District shall be per the requirements listed for each sign type in section 9.5-211, but generally: 
(1)  Of the following signs, only one is allowed per building or premises: 
a.  Low-profile/monument sign. 
b.  Single-tenant wall sign. 
(2)  For the following, more than one sign type may be allowed per tenant or building according to the requirements of this section: 
a.  Window sign. 
b.  Temporary window sign. 
c.  Vertical pole banner sign. 
d.  Awning, canopy, or marquee sign. 
e.  Projecting sign. 
f.  Directional sign. 
g.  Building marker or historical designation tablet. 
(3)  For the following signs, one of each type is allowed per tenant: 
a.  Restaurant menu case. 
b.  Sandwich board. 
c.  Multi-tenant wall sign. 
d.  Banner sign. 
e.  Hanging sign. 
(d)  Required signage. All businesses registered with the City of Lewisville are required to have a minimum of one sign listing the company's name. 
 
This graphic is intended for illustrative purposes only. Signs are subject to the requirements listed in this article. 
(Ord. No. 3987-04-2013 , § 1(Exh. A), 4-1-13)  
Sec. 9.5-208. - Measurement of sign area and height. 
(a)  Area of a sign. The area of a sign shall be measured as follows: 
(1)  For signs in the shape of a square, rectangle, circle, or similar standard geometric shape, the area shall be calculated by using the standard mathematical formula (i.e., height multiplied by width, 3.14 multiplied by radius squared, etc.). 
Examples: 
 
(2)  For signs whose shape is irregular or composed of individually mounted letters, the area shall be calculated by enclosing the sign elements within a polygon of straight line segments. 
Example: 
 
(3)  The area of a spherical, cylindrical, or other three-dimensional sign shall be measured by calculating the area of a two-dimensional drawing of the largest elevation of the sign. 
(4)  Where a sign has two faces, the area of the largest sign face shall be used to determine the area of the sign, provided the two faces are within five degrees of parallel. Where a sign has two or more faces that are greater than five degrees from parallel, the sign area shall either be calculated as the sum of the area of each face, or the sign shall constitute two signs. 
(b)  Height of a sign. The height of all freestanding signs shall be measured from the top edge of the sign and/or support structure to the average finished grade of the ground below the sign and/or support structure. If a sign is located on a mound, berm, valley or other similar area, the height of the sign shall be measured from the grade of the nearest pavement or top of pavement curb, whichever is more restrictive. 
For projecting signs, the height shall be measured by the display surface and shall not include structural supports integral to the sign, except as modified by this article. 
Example: 
 
(Ord. No. 3987-04-2013 , § 1(Exh. A), 4-1-13)  
Sec. 9.5-209. - Required clearances and projection limits. 
(a)  General. Clearances required by this article shall be measured as the shortest distance between the leading edge of the sign and the object or surface requiring clearance. The clearances required by this section represent the minimum standards required. The building official shall have the authority to increase these standards as he deems necessary for safety purposes. 
(b)  Sign projection. No sign shall project above the highest point of the building on which it is placed. The highest point of the building excludes any rooftop mechanical structures, chimneys, elevator shafts, ventilators, or other such appurtenances. Additionally, no sign shall project closer than one foot to the back of a street curb. 
(c)  Clearance of conductors. Signs shall conform to the clearance and projection requirements for conductors as listed in Appendix C or the current city electrical code, whichever is more restrictive. 
(d)  Visibility at intersections. 
(1)  No sign shall obstruct the view in any direction at the intersection of a street or with an alley or driveway. 
a.  Vision at all intersections where streets intersect at or near right angles shall be clear at elevations between two and one-half feet and nine feet above the street grade, within a triangular area formed by extending the two curb lines from their point of intersection 45 feet and connecting these points with an imaginary line, as illustrated in Figure 1. If there are no curbs existing, the triangular area shall be formed by extending the property lines from their point of intersection 25 feet and connecting these points with an imaginary line, thereby making a triangle. 
 
Figure 1 
b.  For streets that do not intersect at right angles, this triangular area may be increased. In such cases, the city engineer or his designee shall have the authority to vary such requirements as deemed necessary to provide safety for both vehicular and pedestrian traffic. 
(e)  Setbacks required. Setbacks for all other sign locations are provided for in other sections of this article. Setbacks shall be measured from the leading edge of the sign to the property line. 
(f)  Other clearances required. 
(1)  Clearance from fire escapes, exits, or standpipes. No sign or sign structure shall be erected in such a manner that any portion of its surface or supports will interfere in any way with the free use of any fire escape, exit, standpipe, or fire department connection. 
(2)  Obstruction of openings. No sign shall obstruct any opening to such an extent that light or ventilation is reduced to a point below that required by the current city building code. 
(3)  Above travel paths. The lowest point of any sign, which extends over an area intended for vehicular use, shall not be less than 14 feet above the finished grade below it. The lowest point of any sign, which extends over an area intended for pedestrian use, shall not be less than seven feet above the finished grade below it. 
a.  Exception: Signs indicating allowable clearances (e.g., drive-through lanes, bridge clearances). 
(g)  Lighting fixture projection. Electrical lighting fixtures and lamps intended to illuminate the face of the sign may be attached to the sign and project beyond the building line or zoning setback for a distance not to exceed six feet, but in no case shall such lighting fixtures extend into clearances required in this article. 
(h)  Right-of-way projection. No sign may project into the public right-of-way, except as modified in this article, but in no case may any sign project closer than one foot to the back of curb. 
(Ord. No. 3987-04-2013 , § 1(Exh. A), 4-1-13)  
Sec. 9.5-210. - Permit exempt signs. 
(a)  General. Certain signs do not require a sign permit. These exemptions shall not be construed as relieving the owner of the sign, device, or decoration from the responsibility of its erection and maintenance in compliance with the provisions of this article and all other laws or ordinances regulating the same. All exempt signs or devices shall not be used or installed in any manner that may result in a potential safety hazard of any type. The signs and devices listed in this section shall not require a sign permit. 
(b)  Building or other decoration. Temporary holiday or festival decorations shall not be considered a sign as defined in this article. Temporary holiday or festival items can only be used during normal calendar holidays. Electrical decorations may require a permit as required by the electrical code. Merchandise or models of products or services incorporated into a window display shall also not be considered a sign as defined in this article. 
(c)  Time, place, and manner regulations. The time, place, and manner regulations in the tables of this section are the only time, place, and manners in which such signs may be erected and maintained. Further, any sign failing to meet these applicable time, place, and manner regulations shall be in violation of this article. 
(d)  Building markers or historic designation tablets.

The City may remove any political sign on property other than private real property remaining beyond 30 days after the election and a $5.00 fee shall be charged for each sign retrieved from the city. 
Place 1,2 	On-premises 	Political signs may only be placed on private real property with the consent of the property owner. 
	Off-premises 	Political signs may only be placed in the city parkway between the curb and property line provided they do not create a safety hazard of any type. 
Manner 	Maximum area 	36 square feet per premises or city right-of-way 
	Maximum height 	8 feet 
	Design standards 	Political signs may not be illuminated or have moving parts, and must be kept in good repair. 
1  Political signs shall not be placed in roadway medians or on city-owned property such as city parks, fire stations, libraries, City Hall, etc. 
2  These restrictions do not apply to existing billboard signs upon which political advertising may be placed.

Sec. 9.5-212. - Prohibited signs. 
Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, the following signs are expressly prohibited by this article. 
(a)  Abandoned signs. 
(b)  Audible signs. Exception: Two-way communication integrated into a menu board sign. 
(c)  Balloons, balloon signs, inflatable signs, pennants and/or streamers. Exception: Balloons, balloon signs, inflatable signs, pennants and/or streamers may be used as part of a grand opening sign permit. 
(d)  Bench signs. 
(e)  Billboards. 
(f)  Feather flags, wind movement or wind devices. Exception: Feather flags, wind movement or wind devices may be used as part of a grand opening sign permit. 
(g)  Flashing signs. 
(h)  Off-premises signs. Exception: Off-premises construction signs. 
(i)  Lighted signs in single-family, two-family (duplex), and OTMU-1 zoning districts. 
(j)  Merchandise, equipment, products, vehicles, or other items which are not available for purchase or rental, but are intended to attract attention, or for identification or advertising purposes. 
(k)  Portable displays. Exception: Sandwich board signs that conform to the requirements of this article are allowed. 
(l)  Searchlights. 
(m)  Signs advertising illegal activities. 
(n)  Signs containing words or symbols that would cause confusion because of their resemblance to highway traffic control or directional signals. 
(o)  Signs on public property or utility easements. Any sign placed on public property or recorded utility easements, including public rights-of-way, without city approval or otherwise allowed by this article shall be removed without notice. 
(p)  Signs on retaining walls, fences, rocks, or natural features. 
(q)  Signs or banners on a pole. Exception: Vertical pole banner signs that conform to the requirements of this article. 
(r)  Temporary signs, unless otherwise permitted by this article. 
(s)  Variable message electronic reader boards. 
(t)  Vehicle signs remaining stationary for a period exceeding 48 hours. 
(u)  Vending machines outside a building. 
(v)  Any other sign not specifically allowed by this ordinance is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 3987-04-2013 , § 1(Exh. A), 4-1-13)  
ARTICLE XIII. - VALET PARKING 
 
Sec. 9.5-213. - Applicability. 
(a)  This article applies to valet parking services conducted within the boundaries of the Old Town entertainment district, as defined in section 9-1 of the city Code. 
(b)  This article does not apply to occasional valet parking services provided: (1) at a private residence; (2) in connection with a social or non-profit fundraising activity; (3) pursuant to a special event permit; or (4) in connection with a city or city-sponsored event. This article also does not apply to a valet parking service that operates (including maneuvering or queuing of vehicles) exclusively on private property. 
( 0011-18-ORD , § II(Exh. A), 2-5-18)  
Sec. 9.5-214. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following words shall have the following meanings: 
Block face means one side of a street between two consecutive intersecting streets. 
Director means the director of the department designated by the city manager to enforce and administer this article, or the director's designated representative. 
Host business means a real property owner or lessee of real property at which a business is operated that intends to provide valet parking service adjacent to its real property. A host business does not include a valet operator. A host business must be an owner or lessee of real property immediately adjacent to the valet parking service area designated on the site map provided with the valet parking license application. 
Right-of-way means any area dedicated for public use as a public street, pedestrian way, or other thoroughfare, including, but not limited to, streets, roadways, parkways, alley, sidewalks, and pedestrian ways. 
Valet operator means a business whose primary purpose is providing valet parking service operations. 
Valet parking service means, regardless of whether a fee is charged: (1) accepting possession of a vehicle on the right-of-way for the purpose of parking the vehicle for the valet operator; (2) retrieving a parked vehicle and returning it to the valet operator on the right-of-way; or (3) using the right-of-way in any manner to maneuver a vehicle for the valet operator. 
( 0011-18-ORD , § II(Exh. A), 2-5-18)  
Sec. 9.5-215. - License. 
(a)  License required. A city-issued valet parking license is required to operate a valet parking service. 
(b)  License application. An application for a valet parking license shall be made by a host business in writing on a form prescribed by the director. All information requested in the application must be provided for an application to be considered complete. Only completed applications shall be processed by the director. 
(1)  License agreement required. A written license agreement between the city and the host business is required to obtain a valet parking license. 
a.  The director may place conditions in a license agreement if he determines such conditions are necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare; to mitigate traffic impacts; and/or to protect surrounding uses. Such conditions shall be made a part of the valet parking license. 
b.  No license agreement shall be valid unless approved by the director. 
c.  The host business and its employees, contractors and agents operating the valet parking service shall comply at all times with the terms contained in the license agreement and this article. 
(2)  Property owner permission required. An applicant that is a lessee of the host business property shall obtain written permission of the property owner to apply for a valet parking license. 
(3)  Written notice to surrounding property owners and businesses required. A host business shall give written notice to all property owners and businesses within 200 feet of the host business property and within 360 feet along the same block face as a requirement for obtaining a license from the city. This notice shall also provide a contact number for the city, where that property owner or business can call to express any concerns or support of the valet parking license application. 
(4)  Fees required. 
a.  Application fee. A nonrefundable application fee in an amount set forth in section 2-201 of the city Code must accompany each application for a valet parking license. 
b.  Fee for queuing spaces. An annual fee in an amount set forth in section 2-201 of the city Code per parallel parking space used for queuing within the right-of-way shall be paid by the host business prior to the issuance of a valet parking license or renewal. 
(c)  Specific requirements. 
(1)  Valet parking services may only operate between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 2:00 a.m., unless further restricted by the license agreement with the city. 
(2)  A minimum of 75 feet for queuing shall be provided. If the proposed queuing area is in the right-of-way, at least three parallel parking spaces of at least 25 feet in length shall be required for operation of the valet parking service. The director, however, may determine that because of specific traffic conditions a greater or lesser number of spaces is required to efficiently operate a valet parking service. 
(3)  Under no circumstance shall a public parking space be designated or reserved for parking a vehicle. Use of such spaces for parking vehicles shall only be allowed on a first-come, first-serve basis. 
(4)  Under no circumstance shall a valet parking service use on-street parking to park vehicles. 
(5)  Queuing spaces and/or stands for a valet parking service may not: 
a.  Be within 20 feet of a crosswalk, intersection, traffic control device or stop sign; 
b.  Be within the right-of-way and within 360 feet in the same block face as another valet stand location or valet queuing located within the right-of-way; 
c.  Be within ten feet of a fire hydrant, fire call box, police or other emergency facility; 
d.  Be within five feet of a driveway; 
e.  Reduce the unobstructed space for the passage of pedestrians to less than four feet; 
f.  Be within three feet in front of or 15 feet behind a sign marking a designated bus stop; or 
g.  Be located in front of a residential lot. 
(6)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, only one valet parking service shall be permitted for every 360 feet per block face. Licenses shall be issued to eligible applicants on a first-come, first-serve basis. A valet parking service, however, shall be required to provide valet parking to any customers visiting businesses located within at least 360 feet of that valet parking service on that same block face. 
(d)  Approval. An application for a valet parking license shall be approved if the director finds: 
(1)  The proposed valet operation will not unreasonably interfere with vehicular or pedestrian traffic; 
(2)  The applicant and/or the proposed valet operator have not violated any conditions of a previous or existing valet parking license within the past three years; 
(3)  The proposed valet parking service operation will not endanger the safety of any person or property; and 
(4)  The proposed valet parking service operation is permitted under this article and all federal (including ADA accessibility requirements), state and local laws. 
(e)  Expiration of license. A valet parking license expires one year from the date of issuance, unless sooner terminated by the director. To renew the license, a new application must be submitted and the requisite fees remitted pursuant to this article. 
(f)  Modification and revocation. The director may, at any time and for any reason, modify the terms of or revoke a valet parking license issued pursuant to this article. 
(g)  Temporary suspension. The director may temporarily suspend the operations of a valet parking service if the right-of-way used by the valet parking service is needed for an emergency or temporary use, including, but not limited to, city-sponsored special events and the construction, maintenance, or repair of a street or utility. 
(h)  Appeals. Any person aggrieved by a decision of the director under this article may appeal the decision to city manager by filing a notice of written appeal to the director within ten business days of the director's decision. 
(i)  No rights established. Nothing in this article is intended to establish any legal real property interest in operating a valet parking service or any legal property interest in a valet parking license. 
( 0011-18-ORD , § II(Exh. A), 2-5-18)  
Sec. 9.5-216. - Violations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to provide or engage in valet parking services without a valid valet parking license issued pursuant to this article. A valet parking license that has expired or that has been suspended or revoked is not a valid license. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a valet parking operator to stop or direct traffic. 
(c)  Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions or terms of this article shall be deemed guilty of an offense. Each and every day a violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
( 0011-18-ORD , § II(Exh. A), 2-5-18)  
Secs. 9.5-217—9.5-240. - Reserved.  
APPENDIX A. - GUIDELINES FOR SIGNAGE IN OLD TOWN 
(a)  Intent. This section presents guidelines for the design of new and renovated signs in Lewisville's Old Town District. Organized into a series of relevant design topics, these guiding principles help to frame the prescriptive requirements of the Old Town Sign Ordinance. Within each category, individual policies and design guidelines are presented, which the Old Town Design Review Committee may reference in determining the appropriateness of the work proposed. 
(b)  Overview. Signs are an integral part of the built environment and if designed well, can provide direction, encourage business growth, and enhance an area's image. If designed poorly, they can confuse viewers, stifle business, and detract from the appearance and perception of the public realm. 
(c)  Purpose. A sign typically serves two functions: to attract attention and to convey information, essentially identifying the business or services offered within a building. Architectural elements of a building, window displays, outdoor seating, and other streetscape elements can also work to supplement signage. For example, the building front alone can serve as an attention-getting function, allowing the sign to be focused on conveying information. 
 
 
 
(d)  Core Principles. In the determination of appropriate sign design, the following principles should be observed: 
(1)  Signs are subordinate to the building architecture 
(2)  Signs are part of a larger streetscape 
(3)  Signs are intended for different speeds of traffic 
Consider the building front as part of an overall sign program. Signs should be coordinated within the overall facade composition so that it is in proportion to the building and does not dominate the appearance. 
Additionally, a master sign plan for the entire building should be developed to guide design decisions for individual signs. This is especially important where the use of contemporary building forms and styles in conjunction with several colorful, attention-getting signs are the norm. Typical "strip-commercial" development patterns are inappropriate in Old Town. 
A sign should appear to be in scale with the facade. Locate signage on a building so that it emphasizes design elements of the facade. Mount signs to fit within existing architectural features and use the shape of the sign to reinforce the horizontal lines of moldings and transoms seen from the street. 
The placement or location of a sign is perhaps the most critical factor in maintaining the order and integrity of Old Town. Consistent placement of signs according to building type, size, location, and even materials, creates a visual pattern that its audience can easily interpret and utilize to the mutual benefit of merchants, tourists, and customers. 
 
 
 
(e)  Design Elements. 
(1)  Color. The color palette for signs should be drawn from those approved by the National Trust for Historic Preservation. Colors should relate to each other as well as their surroundings. For example, a very light or white background on a sign may be too stark for its context and compete with the architectural elements of the building. Also limit the number of colors used on a sign. In general, no more than three to five colors are recommended. 
(2)  Typeface. Typical typefaces found in Old Town are constructed from serif-style fonts. Serif-style fonts tend to be more legible at larger sizes while sans-serif fonts are more appropriate for supporting detail text. A mixture of fonts and lettering sizes can add interest to a sign, provided that no more than two are used. Avoid hard-to-read or overly intricate typeface styles. 
 
(3)  Shape. Signs in Old Town should have detailed edges. For example, rectangular signs may have notched or rounded edges, and should relate to the architectural character of the building. An elliptical sign may be more appropriate as a projecting sign than as a wall sign if the shape of the sign is discordant with the architecture of the building. However, the same elliptical sign could be used to highlight the rhythm of architectural elements by locating it over a column or centered within a structural bay. 
 
(4)  Materials. Sign materials should be consistent with those listed in the Old Town Sign Ordinance. Additionally, monument signs should reflect the architectural style of the buildings on the same lot. For example, a monument sign for a brick building should be made of brick as well. Plastic is not an allowed material in Old Town. 
(5)  Lighting Type. Lighting types should also be consistent with those listed in the Sign Ordinance. Period style lighting fixtures should be considered. For projecting or wall signs, goose-neck style fixtures are recommended. 
 
(6)  Legibility. Care should be given to the intended audience of a sign and its readability. Positive contrast, or lighter text on a darker background, tends to be easier to read. Negative contrast, or darker text on a lighter background, can sometimes cause the lettering to develop a fuzzy edge. [2] 
Studies show that seven words are the most a viewer can effectively read. [3] 
 
(7)  Variety and Creativity. Variety in sign design should be encouraged. Most businesses choosing to locate in Old Town, particularly in the Old Town Center, are small family-owned enterprises each with their own personalized way of operating. This social context offers the community an opportunity to develop signs that are home-grown and unique. [4] 
Quality and craftsmanship should be a part of every sign in Old Town. Using a symbol for a sign is encouraged. Symbols add interest to the street, can be read quickly, and are remembered better than written words. 
 
(8)  Sign Quality. Business signage can be the first impression a potential customer receives, and should incorporate the same level of care and quality found inside the business. A quality sign typically includes a balance of font styles and sizes, colors, graphics, durable materials, and supports the building architecture. 
 
(9)  Audience. Sign design should consider the viewer or "end user" of the sign. Larger signs are more appropriate for faster moving traffic, such as vehicles, where the time the viewer has to identify the sign, understand it, and react to it is shorter than pedestrian traffic. For vehicular-oriented signs, greater spacing between text and larger lettering is appropriate. For pedestrian-oriented signs, text may be smaller and still achieve legibility. 
 
(10)  Sign Hierarchy. Signs should work together in a hierarchical relationship. The larger, primary signs of a business such as a monument sign or a wall sign would most likely express the main idea of the business, including the name and perhaps an iconic graphic representing the industry or character of the place. Secondary signs, such as window and hanging signs, strengthen the overall theme offering supporting information. For example, a cafe may contain the name of the business on the wall sign and then in smaller lettering on the window, list items offered (e.g., coffee, tea, pastries, etc.). In this way, the information is organized in the same format it is processed by the viewer: first locating the destination, then selecting options at that location. Duplicating information on the same facade does not utilize the allowable sign area to its full potential and is discouraged in Old Town. 
(11)  Historic Context. Traditionally, a variety of signs existed within the Old Town District: 
 
•  Small, freestanding signs mounted on a pole or post; located near the sidewalk because the primary structure or business was set back from the street (e.g., an area with residential character), printed on both sides. 
•  Medium-sized, square or rectangular-shaped signs that projected from the building above the awnings or canopies, printed on both sides. 
•  Small horizontally-oriented rectangular signs that protruded from the building below the awnings or canopies but above pedestrians' heads, printed on both sides. 
•  Medium to large, horizontally oriented rectangular signs attached flat against the building, above and/or below the awnings, printed on one side only. 
•  Window signs, painted on glass, used at the street level and on upper floors. 
 
Signs that were historically mounted on a building's exterior advertised the primary business or service. Typically, this use occupied a street-level space and sometimes upper floors as well. In the case of a large structure that included several businesses on upper floors, the name of the building itself was displayed on an exterior sign and tenants relied on a directory placed at the street level. Signs were designed to fit within architectural features and in many cases, were mounted flush above the storefront, just over moldings. Others were located between columns or centered in "panels" on a building face. This method enabled the viewer to see the design and character of individual structures. Generally, signs allowed in Old Town fall into one of three categories: primary, secondary, and temporary. 
 
•  A primary sign represents the owner's largest sign expense and is likely the most important of the sign types. Only one primary sign is allowed per business, per building. 
•  Secondary signs are utilized in addition to the primary building sign and generally tied to an architectural feature. Typically, a secondary sign is an awning, projecting, or window sign. The secondary sign is generally intended to capture the attention of a pedestrian walking on the sidewalk, while the primary sign's audience is typically driving past in a vehicle. 
•  Tertiary signs are also intended for pedestrian view and may consist of hanging, sandwich board, or restaurant menu cases. These signs are allowed for each tenant of a building. 
(f)  Design of Sign Types. 
(1)  Awning, Canopy, or Marquee Signs. Awning and canopy structures should be of a visually uniform style on a building. For example, it would be inappropriate to have metal canopies, canvas awnings, and bullnose-style awnings on the same facade or along two facades sharing a corner. However, different styles of awning or canopy structures could be located on opposite facades where they cannot be seen at the same time. 
 
 
(2)  Wall Signs. In many cases, turn-of-the century building types common in Lewisville have a sign band. This is the ideal location for the primary building sign. The sign band is typically located above the transom and below the second-floor windows. When utilizing the sign band as the sign placement location, it is important to respect the borders. The sign should not overlap or crowd the top, bottom, or ends of the sign band. When feasible, place a wall sign so that it aligns with others on the block. 
 
(3)  Window Signs and Displays. While window displays are not reviewed by the OTDRC, their use is very important to retailers. The attractiveness of a display is likely the highest contributing factor to whether or not a pedestrian will enter a store, and its design should be carefully planned. 
 
The OTDRC will recognize and assume oversight of signs within a store that are obviously intended to be viewed through the window. 
Use of reflective, tinted, or coated glass is not appropriate for windows and doors of ground floor commercial buildings in Old Town. Additionally, window coverings should not be used to obscure transparency. 
(4)  Hanging Signs. A small hanging sign may be easier for a pedestrian to read than other sign types, and is encouraged. Hanging signs should be located near the business entrance, just above the door or to the side of it. A hanging sign should be mounted perpendicular with the building facade. 
 
(5)  Projecting Signs. Projecting signs should be larger than hanging signs, mounted higher, and centered on the facade or positioned at the corner of a building. For buildings located at a street intersection, a projecting sign not exceeding 30 square feet may be considered at the corner facing the street intersection, provided there are no projecting signs on the building facades facing the intersecting streets. 
 
(6)  Multi-Tenant Wall Signs. Where several businesses share a building, the signs should be coordinated. If several smaller signs are used, they should be located in harmony with the building architecture, taking into account bay spacing, windows, or other elements that establish an architectural rhythm. Use similar forms or backgrounds for the signs to tie them together visually and make them easier to read. Consistency among the signs should be balanced with sign originality to maintain legibility and character. 
 
(7)  Low-Profile/Monument Signs. Low-profile/monument signs should match the architectural style and material of buildings on the same lot. 
 
(Ord. No. 3987-04-2013 , § 1(Exh. A), 4-1-13)

Chapter 10 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1]
