(d)  The control authority shall not issue a permit unless the applicant submits for inspection by the control authority, the vehicle the applicant proposes to use to transport waste and the vehicle is found by the control authority to be constructed and equipped in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(e)  A permit is not transferable. 
(f)  Permits must be renewed annually and each vehicle must be inspected prior to renewal. 
(g)  No permit issued by the city shall approve the hauling of materials that are hazardous in nature. Only those wastes designated on a vehicle's permit shall be transported by such vehicle. 
(h)  Each applicant must specify the disposal site to be used for the authorized disposal of waste. The control authority shall be immediately notified of additional disposal sites used during the permit period. 
(i)  Permits shall be issued by the control authority. 
(j)  The permittee shall be inspected periodically as directed by the control authority. 
(k)  The control authority shall not issue a permit to an applicant until the appropriate established fee is paid. A person shall pay a fee which is set out in section 2-201 for each vehicle operated by the person. Additional vehicles permitted will maintain the same renewal date as the initial vehicle. 
(l)  The control authority shall number permits consecutively, and each permit holder shall cause to be displayed on each side of each vehicle, in a color contrasting with the background in three-inch letters or larger, the business name, the TDH registration number, and the following: 
LVTX (permit #) 
The permit holder shall place the business name, the TDH registration number and the vehicle permit number on each side of the vehicle before the vehicle is operated in the city. The permit holder shall keep the permit, or a copy of the permit, in the vehicle at all times. 
(Ord. No. 1583-11-90, § 3, 11-19-90)  
Sec. 16-87. - Same—Denial, suspension, revocation. 
(a)  The control authority may deny a permit if it is determined that an applicant is not qualified under this article and may suspend or revoke a permit if it is determined that a permittee: 
(1)  Has violated a provision of this article; 
(2)  Has failed to pay a required fee; 
(3)  Has failed to comply with maintenance or inspection requirements; or 
(4)  Has failed to submit completed trip tickets to the control authority. 
(b)  After suspension under this section, a permittee may file a request for reinstatement of the permit. If all violations have been corrected, precautions have been taken to prevent future violations and all required fees have been paid, the control authority may reinstate the permit. 
(c)  The control authority may revoke, for a period of one year or less, all city permits held by a waste transporter if the transporter or an employee of the transporter, violates this article, any rule or regulation promulgated by the control authority, applicable provisions of other city ordinances, or state or federal regulations. 
(d)  A permittee whose permit is suspended or revoked shall not collect, transport or dispose of any waste materials within the jurisdiction of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1583-11-90, § 13, 11-19-90)  
Sec. 16-88. - Same—Appeals. 
If the control authority suspends or revokes a permit, he shall send to the permit holder, by certified mail, return receipt requested, written notice of his action. If issuance of a permit is denied, the reason for the denial shall be explained to the applicant verbally or in writing. In each case, the applicant shall be informed of his right to appeal the decision to the industrial waste hearing board in accordance with the procedure outlined in section 16-51 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 1583-11-90, § 15, 11-19-90)  
Sec. 16-89. - Waste transporting vehicles—Maintenance. 
(a)  A waste transporter shall: 
(1)  Maintain hoses, tanks, valves, pumps, cylinders, diaphragms, pipes, connections and other appurtenances on a vehicle in good repair and free from leaks; 
(2)  Provide a safety plug or cap for each valve of a tank; and 
(3)  Cause a vehicle exterior to be clean and the vehicle odor-free at the beginning of each workday. 
(b)  The control authority may cause to be impounded a vehicle which is being operated in violation of this section, and he may authorize the holding of the vehicle until the violation is corrected. The control authority may also revoke the permit of an improperly operated vehicle. If a vehicle is impounded or if a permit is revoked, an appeal may be filed by the transporter pursuant to section 16-88. 
(Ord. No. 1583-11-90, § 4, 11-19-90)  
Sec. 16-90. - Same—Inspection. 
A waste transporter's vehicle shall be inspected by the control authority prior to the issuance of a vehicle permit with qualifications as follows: 
(1)  Use a vehicle with a single tank as an integral portion of vehicle to transport wastes. Portable tanks or other containers temporarily installed in, or on, vehicles are prohibited. 
(2)  Piping, valves and connectors shall be permanently attached to tank and/or vehicle. 
(3)  Tank shall be liquid tight. 
(4)  Tanks, piping, valves and connections shall be constructed so that every interior and exterior portion can be easily cleaned. 
(5)  Inlets, outlets, and any other opening or connection of the vehicle shall be constructed so that collected material will not spill during filling, transferring or transporting. 
(6)  Outlets, pumps, valves, diaphragms and other appurtenances shall be of a design and type suitable for the type of waste handled, capable of operation without spillage, spray or leakage and capable of being easily disassembled for cleaning. 
(Ord. No. 1583-11-90, § 5, 11-19-90)  
Sec. 16-91. - Responsibilities of a waste transporter. 
(a)  Before accepting waste for transport, a waste transporter shall determine the nature of the material to be transported and that the equipment is sufficient to properly handle the job without spillage or leakage. Upon delivery of the waste to the disposer, the transporter shall inform the disposer of the nature of the waste. 
(b)  A transporter with a city waste transporter permit shall not transport materials that are hazardous as defined in section 16-26 in vehicles permitted by the city for transporting waste. 
(c)  A transporter holding a city permit must use a disposal site permitted and approved by the city, state or federal government. 
(d)  A manifest system, consisting of a five-part trip ticket, shall be used to document the generation, transportation and disposal of all waste regulated by this article generated in the city. The control authority shall not issue trip tickets to an applicant until the appropriate established fee is paid. A person shall pay a fee which is set out in section 2-201 for trip tickets and trip tickets shall be used as follows: 
(1)  The trip tickets shall be obtained by the transporter from the control authority. 
(2)  A transporter shall complete one trip ticket for each location serviced, with the exception of chemical/portable toilet companies servicing their own units. Chemical/portable toilet companies servicing their own units shall complete one trip ticket for each vehicle load transported. Proof of units collected may be required at the discretion of the control authority. 
(3)  The white copy of the trip ticket, signed by the transporter and generator at the time of waste collection and yellow copy maintained by the generator. 
(4)  The white copy of the trip ticket signed by the disposer at the time of disposal and pink copy maintained by the disposer. 
(5)  The green copy of the trip ticket maintained by the transporter and the gold copy of the trip ticket to be returned to the generator. 
(6)  The white copy of all completed trip tickets shall be returned, by the transporter, to the control authority within 30 days after completion of the trip ticket, except when an alternate schedule has been approved by the control authority. 
(7)  A copy of all trip tickets shall be maintained by the transporter for a period of two years. 
(Ord. No. 1583-11-90, § 6, 11-19-90; Ord. No. 2210-4-97, § I, 4-14-97)  
Sec. 16-92. - Rules and regulations. 
The control authority may promulgate rules and regulations and may undertake immediate action as necessary to carry out the provisions of this article and protect the public from health and safety hazards. The control authority may amend any permit issued hereunder to ensure compliance with applicable laws and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2210-4-97, § I, 4-14-97)  
Sec. 16-93. - Plan submittal. 
Required engineered plans and/or drawings shall be submitted to the city department of community development, building inspection division. All sizing of grease receptacles, sand/grit interceptors, oil interceptors, and acid/alkali dilution basins must be approved by the city. 
(1)  [The following are required to be submitted for] grease receptacles, sand/grit interceptors, oil interceptors, and acid/alkali dilution basins: 
a.  Two sets of engineer-designed and stamped drawings. 
b.  Required one-fourth-inch scale. 
c.  Size calculations. 
d.  Complete cross-sectional details. 
e.  Location of unit. 
f.  Combined inspection port. 
g.  Influent and effluent inspection ports. 
(2)  Reserved. 
(Ord. No. 2210-4-97, § I, 4-14-97)  
Secs. 16-94—16-98. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - PRIVATE RESIDENTIAL SEWER SERVICE LINE CLEANING 
 
Sec. 16-99. - Cleaning and repair of private residential sanitary sewer service lines. 
(a)  The property owner/occupant is responsible for cleaning/clearing all stoppages in the private residential sanitary sewer service line from the house to the tap at the city sewer main. The city will not clean/clear any stoppages located in the private sanitary sewer service line regardless of the location of the stoppage. 
(b)  The property owner/occupant is responsible for all repairs, including emergency repairs, to the private residential sanitary sewer service line from the house to the house side edge of the sidewalk if a sidewalk is present, or to the house side edge of the street pavement/back of curb if no sidewalk is present. If the residential sanitary sewer service line runs into the alley, the property owner/occupant is responsible for all repairs from the house to the house side edge of the alley pavement. 
(c)  The city will schedule and investigate reported private residential sanitary sewer service line defects that are located between the house side edge of the sidewalk, the house side edge of the street pavement/back of curb, or the house side edge of the alley pavement, and the city sewer main. If the city confirms that there is a defect in the private residential sanitary sewer service line, located between the house side edge of the sidewalk, street pavement/back of curb, or alley pavement and the city sewer main, the city will schedule and complete repairs to the service line at no cost to the property owner/occupant. 
(Ord. No. 3797-09-2010 , § 2, 9-13-10; Ord. No. 3981-02-2013 , § 1, 2-4-13)  
Sec. 16-100. - Procedure. 
(a)  The property owner/occupant is responsible for cleaning/clearing all private residential sanitary sewer service line stoppages. 
(b)  If the property owner/occupant determines via camera inspection by a licensed plumber, or by other valid means, that there is a defective service line pipe located between the house side edge of the sidewalk, street, or alley pavement and the city sewer main, the owner/occupant or their plumber should contact the city to schedule an inspection. 
(c)  The city may reverify property owner/occupant camera inspection report. If there is no functional clean out connection near the street for access to the service line, the property owner/occupant, who must be at least 18 years of age or older, must sign a consent/release form provided by the city before the city can perform the reverification camera inspection using the clean out near the house. The property owner/occupant is responsible for locating any clean out, or installing one if one does not exist. City employees shall not enter onto private property to perform any work to locate the clean out or make any alteration to the clean out. If the camera inspection confirms the location of the defect within the edge of the sidewalk, street or alley pavement, the city will schedule and complete repairs at no cost to the owner/occupant. 
(d)  The maintenance and repair of private residential sanitary sewer service lines is the responsibility of the property owner. All city codes and ordinances must be followed regarding repair work. 
(Ord. No. 3797-09-2010 , § 2, 9-13-10; Ord. No. 3981-02-2013 , § 2, 2-4-13)  
Secs. 16-101—16-110. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - INDUSTRIAL WASTES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, adopted Feb. 4, 2010, repealed Art. III, §§ 16-111—16-137, in its entirety and replaced it with a new Art. III, §§ 16-111—16-137. Former Art. III pertained to industrial wastes and derived from Ord. No. 2540-2-2000, § I, 2-7-00; Ord. No. 2795-04-2002, § 1, 4-1-02. 
 
Sec. 16-111. - Compliance with other authority. 
(a)  Compliance with federal authority. The city shall comply with, enforce and adopt all federal general pretreatment regulations and federal categorical pretreatment regulations, including the implementation of a pretreatment program approved by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. Industrial users within the jurisdiction of this article shall comply with all applicable state and federal laws, including the Clean Water Act (33 United States Code § 1251 et seq.), the federal general pretreatment regulations and with those federal categorical pretreatment standards applicable to each. The categorical pretreatment standards found in 40 CFR Chapter I, Subchapter N is hereby incorporated. 
(b)  Compliance with state authority. The city shall comply with, enforce and adopt all applicable sections of V.T.C.A., Texas Water Code Ch. 26, as it now exists or as hereafter amended. 
(c)  Right of revision. The city reserves the right to revise and to establish, by ordinance or into industrial waste permits, more stringent standards or requirements on discharges to the POTW, in accordance with 40 CFR 403.13(c)(3)(f). 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-112. - Objectives. 
The objective of this article is to establish the responsibilities of the city, industry and the public to implement national pretreatment standards by providing regulations which: 
(1)  Prevent the introduction of pollutants into the city's POTW, which will interfere with the operation of a POTW, including interference with its use or disposal of municipal sludge; 
(2)  Prevent the introduction of pollutants into the city's POTW, which will pass through the treatment works or otherwise be incompatible with such works; 
(3)  Improve opportunities to recycle and reclaim municipal and industrial wastewaters and sludges; and 
(4)  Protect the general public and the city's POTW personnel. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-113. - Definitions. 
As used in this article: 
Act: The Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as it now exists or as hereafter amended, (33 United States Code § 1251 et seq.). 
Amalgam process wastewater: means any wastewater generated and discharged by a dental discharger through the practice of dentistry that may contain dental amalgam. 
Amalgam separator: means a collection device designed to capture and remove dental amalgam from the amalgam process wastewater of a dental facility. 
Approval authority: The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ). 
Authorized official: A responsible corporate officer if the industrial user is a corporation, a general partner or proprietor if the industrial user is a partnership or sole proprietorship, respectively, a director or highest official appointed to oversee the operation and performance activities if the industrial user is a federal, state or local government or a representative of these individuals who is responsible for the overall operation of the facility or for environmental matters and being so, is authorized, in writing, to the control authority. 
Best management practices or BMPs: Schedules of activities, prohibitions of practices, maintenance procedures, and other management practices to implement the prohibitions listed in 40 CFR Sections 403.5(a)(1) and (b). BMPs also include treatment requirements, operating procedures, and practices to control plant site runoff, spillage or leaks, sludge or waste disposal, or drainage from raw materials storage. 
BOD: Biochemical oxygen demand defined as the quantity of oxygen by weight, expressed in mg/L, utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory conditions for five days at a temperature of 20 degrees Centigrade; 
Bypass: The intentional diversion of a wastestream from any portion of a user's treatment facility. 
Categorical industrial user: An industrial user subject to a categorical pretreatment standard or categorical standard. 
Categorical pretreatment standard or categorical standard: Any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by EPA in accordance with sections 307(b) and (c) of the Clean Water Act (33 U.S.C. section 1317) that apply to a specific category of industrial users and that appear in 40 CFR Chapter I, Subchapter N, parts 405-471. 
Chemical oxygen demand or COD: The quantity of oxygen utilized in the chemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedures, usually expressed as a concentration in mg/l. 
City: The City of Lewisville, Texas, or any authorized person acting in its behalf. 
Code of Federal Regulations or CFR: A codification of the general and permanent rules published in the federal register by the executive departments and agencies of the federal government. 
Composite sample: A sample that is collected over time, formed either by continuous sampling or by mixing discrete samples. The sample may be composited either as a time composite sample: composed of discrete sample aliquots collected in one container at constant time intervals providing representative samples irrespective of stream flow; or as a flow proportional composite sample: collected either as a constant sample volume at time intervals proportional to stream flow, or collected by increasing the volume of each aliquot as the flow increases while maintaining a constant time interval between the aliquots, or as defined by 40 CFR 403 Appendix E, as it now exists or as hereafter amended. 
Control authority or CA: The director of public services (or other official designated by the city manager) of the city, or his duly authorized agent or representative. 
Control point: A point of access to a course of discharge before the discharge mixes with other discharges in the public sewer, also known as an inspection port and/or control manhole. 
Daily maximum: The maximum allowable discharge of pollutant during a calendar day. Where daily maximum limitations are expressed in units of mass, the daily maximum is the total mass discharged over the course of the day. Where daily maximum limitations are expressed in terms of concentration, the daily maximum is the arithmetic average measurement of the pollutant concentration derived from all measurements taken that day. 
Dental amalgam: means an alloy of elemental mercury and other metal(s) that is used in the practice of dentistry. 
Dental discharger: means a facility where the practice of dentistry is performed, including, but not limited to, institutions, permanent or temporary offices, clinics, home offices, and facilities owned and operated by federal, state or local governments, that discharges wastewater to a publicly owned treatment works (POTW). Dental dischargers are regulated industrial users according to 40 CFR Part 441. 
Discharge: To deposit, conduct, drain, emit, throw, run, allow to seep, or otherwise release or dispose of, or to cause, allow, permit, or suffer any of these acts or omissions. 
Domestic sewage or wastewater: Water-borne waste normally discharged from the sanitary conveniences of dwellings (including apartments, houses and hotels), office buildings, factories and institutions, free from storm surface water and industrial waste. 
Environmental Protection Agency or EPA: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency or, where appropriate, the regional water management division director, or other duly authorized official of said agency. 
Gallons per day or GPD: A measurement of flow rate. 
Grab sample: A sample which is taken from a wastestream without regard to the flow in the wastestream and over a period of time not to exceed fifteen (15 minutes), or as defined by 40 CFR 403 Appendix E, as it now exists or as hereafter amended. 
Hazardous waste: As defined by 40 CFR 261, as it now exists or as hereafter amended. 
Indirect discharge: The introduction of pollutants into the POTW from any non-domestic source within the jurisdiction of this article, [40 CFR 403.3(i), as it now exists or as hereafter amended]. 
Industrial user or user or IU: A source of indirect discharge, [40 CFR 403.3(j), as it now exists or as hereafter amended]. 
Industrial waste: Waste resulting from any process of industry, manufacturing, trade or business. 
Industrial waste surcharge: The charge assessed an industrial user for discharging into the city's sewer system, an industrial waste which is of greater strength than domestic sewage. 
Inspection port: See definition of Control point. 
Instantaneous maximum allowable discharge limit: The maximum concentration of a pollutant allowed to be discharged at any time, determined from the analysis of any discrete or composited sample collected, independent of the industrial flow rate and duration of the sampling event. 
Interceptor: A device designed and installed to separate and retain deleterious, hazardous or undesirable matter from normal wastewater and permit normal sewage or liquid waste to discharge into the disposal system by gravity. 
Interference: A discharge, which alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources, inhibits or disrupts the POTW, its treatment processes or operations or its sludge processes, use or disposal; and therefore, is a cause of a violation of the city's NPDES or TPDES permit, or of the prevention of sewage sludge use or disposal in compliance with any of the following statutory/regulatory provisions or permits issued there under, or any more stringent state or local regulations: Section 405 of the Clean Water Act; the Solid Waste Disposal Act, including Title II commonly referred to as the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA); any state regulations contained in any state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to Subtitle D of the Solid Waste Disposal Act; the Clean Air Act; the Toxic Substances Control Act; and the Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act; or as defined by 40 CFR 403.3(k), as it now exists or as hereafter amended. 
Medical waste: Isolation wastes, infectious agents, human blood and blood products, pathological wastes, sharps, body parts, contaminated bedding, surgical wastes, potentially contaminated laboratory wastes, and dialysis wastes. 
mg/L: Milligrams per liter as a weight-to-volume ratio, equivalent to parts per million. 
Monthly average limit: The highest allowable average of "daily discharges" over a calendar month, calculated as the sum of all "daily discharges" measured during a calendar month divided by the number of "daily discharges" measured during that month. 
National categorical standard orpretreatment standard: Any regulations containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the approval authority in accordance with Sections 307(b) and (c) of the Clean Water Act, that apply to a specific category of industrial user. This term includes prohibitive discharge limits established pursuant to 40 CFR 403.5. in accordance with 40 CFR 403.3(l), as it now exists or as hereafter amended. 
New source: 
(1)  Any building, structure, facility, or installation from which there is (or may be) a discharge of pollutants, the construction of which commenced after the publication of proposed pretreatment standards under Section 307(c) of the Act which will be applicable to such source if such standards are thereafter promulgated in accordance with that section, provided that: 
a.  The building, structure, facility, or installation is constructed at a site at which no other source is located; or 
b.  The building, structure, facility, or installation totally replaces the process or production equipment that causes the discharge of pollutants at an existing source; or 
c.  The production or wastewater generating processes of the building, structure, facility, or installation is substantially independent of an existing source at the same site. In determining whether these are substantially independent, factors such as the extent to which the new facility is integrated with the existing plant, and the extent to which the new facility is engaged in the same general type of activity as the existing source, should be considered. 
(2)  Construction on a site at which an existing source is located results in a modification rather than a new source if the construction does not create a new building, structure, facility, or installation meeting the criteria of sections (1)b or (1)c above, but otherwise alters, replaces, or adds to existing process or production equipment. 
(3)  Construction of a new source as defined under this paragraph has commenced if the owner or operator has: 
a.  Begun, or caused to begin, as part of a continuous on-site construction program: 
1.  Any placement, assembly, or installation of facilities or equipment; or 
2.  Significant site preparation work including clearing, excavation, or removal of existing buildings, structures, or facilities which is necessary for the placement, assembly, or installation of new source facilities or equipment; or 
b.  Entered into a binding contractual obligation for the purchase of facilities or equipment, which are intended to be used in its operation within a reasonable time. Options to purchase or contracts which can be terminated or modified without substantial loss, and contracts for feasibility, engineering, and design studies do not constitute a contractual obligation under this paragraph; or as defined by 40 CFR 403.3(m), as it now exists or as hereafter amended. 
Non-contact cooling water: Water used for cooling which does not come into direct contact with any raw material, intermediate product, waste product, or finished product. 
Normal domestic sewage: Normal sewage for the city in which the concentration of total suspended solids and five-day 20° C biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) is established at 240 milligrams per liter, by weight, on the basis of the normal daily concentration of 0.20 pounds per capita, per 100 gallons. 
NPDES permit: The National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit issued to the POTW pursuant to Section 402 of the Clean Water Act. 
Pass through: A discharge which exits the POTW into waters of the United States in quantities or concentrations which, alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources, is a cause of a violation of any requirements of the city's NPDES permit, including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a violation; or as defined by 40 CFR 403.3(p), as it now exists or as hereafter amended. 
Person: Any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trusts, estate, governmental entity, or any other legal entity; or their legal representatives, agents, or assigns. This definition includes all federal, state, and local governmental entities. 
pH: The logarithm (Base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration (the negative log of the hydrogen ion). 
Pollutant: Dredge spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, filter backwash, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, medical wastes, chemical wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discarded equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt, municipal, agricultural and industrial wastes, and concentration characteristics of certain wastewater. 
Pollution: A condition created by the presence of harmful or objectionable material, pollutants. 
Pretreatment: The reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater prior to, or in lieu of, introducing such pollutants into the POTW. This reduction or alteration can be obtained by physical, chemical, or biological processes; by process changes; or by other means, except by diluting the concentration of the pollutants unless allowed by an applicable pretreatment standard, or as defined by 40 CFR 403.3(s), as it now exists or as hereafter amended. 
Pretreatment requirements: Any substantive or procedural requirement related to pretreatment imposed on a user, other than a pretreatment standard, or as defined by 40 CFR 403.3(r), as it now exists or as hereafter amended. 
Pretreatment standards: Any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits including, but not limited to, national pretreatment standards, categorical pretreatment standards, prohibited discharge limits and local discharge limits. 
Process wastewater: Any water which, during manufacturing or processing, comes into direct contact with or results from the production or use of any raw material, intermediate product, finished product, by-product, or waste product. 
Prohibited discharge standards or prohibited discharges: Absolute prohibitions against the discharge of certain substances; these prohibitions appear in subsection 16-114(a) of this article. 
Publicly owned treatment works or POTW: The city's publicly owned treatment works including any devices and systems used in storage, treatment, recycling and reclamation of municipal sewage or industrial waste of a liquid nature. This definition also includes sewers, pipes and other conveyances only if they convey wastewater to the POTW treatment plant. The term also includes the city which has jurisdiction over the discharges to and the discharges from such treatment works. 
Resource Conservation and Recovery Act or RCRA: Statutory provisions and regulations as provided in Title II of the Solid Waste Disposal Act (SWDA). 
Sanitary sewer: A public sewer that conveys domestic wastewater or industrial wastewater or a combination of both, and into which stormwater, surface water, ground water, and other polluted wastes are not intentionally passed. 
Shall: Wherever used in this article will be interpreted in its mandatory sense; "may" is permissive. 
Significant industrial user or SIU: 
(1)  A user subject to categorical pretreatment standards; or 
(2)  A user that: 
a.  Discharges an average of 25,000 gpd or more of process wastewater to the POTW (excluding sanitary, non-contact cooling, and boiler blowdown wastewater); 
b.  Contributes a process wastestream which makes up five percent or more of the average dry weather hydraulic or organic capacity of the POTW treatment plant; or 
c.  Is designated as such by the control authority on the basis that it has a reasonable potential for adversely affecting the POTW's operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement. 
(3)  Upon a finding that a user meeting the criteria in subsection (2) above has no reasonable potential for adversely affecting the POTW's operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement, the control authority may at any time, on its own initiative or in response to a petition received from a user, and in accordance with procedures in 40 CFR 403.8(f)(6), determine that such user should not be considered a significant industrial user; or as defined by 40 CFR 403.3(v), as it now exists or as hereafter amended. 
Significant  noncompliance or SNC: As defined by 40 CFR 403.8(f)(2)(viii)(A-H), as it now exists or as hereafter amended, which includes: 
(1)  Chronic violations of wastewater discharge limits, defined here as those in which 66 percent or more of all measurements taken for the same pollutant parameter during a six-month period exceed (by any magnitude) a numeric pretreatment standard or requirement, including instantaneous limits, as defined by 40 CFR 403.3(I); 
(2)  Technical review criteria (TRC) violations, defined here as those in which 33 percent or more of all of the measurements taken for the same pollutant parameter during a six-month period equal or exceed the product of the numeric pretreatment standard or requirement including instantaneous limits, as defined by 40 CFR 403.3(I) multiplied by the applicable TRC (TRC = 1.4 for BOD, TSS, fats, oil, and grease, and 1.2 for all other pollutants except pH); 
(3)  Any other violation of a pretreatment standard or requirement as defined by 40 CFR 403.3(I) (daily maximum, long-term average, instantaneous limit, or narrative standard) that the POTW determines has caused, alone or in combination with other discharges, interference or pass through (including endangering the health of POTW personnel or the general public); 
(4)  Any discharge of a pollutant that has caused imminent endangerment to human health, welfare or to the environment or has resulted in the POTW's exercise of its emergency authority under paragraph (f)(1)(vi)(B) of 40 CFR 403.8 to halt or prevent such a discharge; 
(5)  Failure to meet, within 90 days after the schedule date, a compliance schedule milestone contained in a local control mechanism or enforcement order for starting construction, completing construction, or attaining final compliance; 
(6)  Failure to provide, within 45 days after the due date, required reports such as baseline monitoring reports, 90-day compliance reports, periodic self-monitoring reports, and reports on compliance with compliance schedules; 
(7)  Failure to accurately report noncompliance; or 
(8)  Any other violation or group of violations, which may include a violation of best management practices, which the POTW determines will adversely affect the operation of the local pretreatment program. 
Slug: Any discharge of a non-routine, episodic nature, including but not limited to, an accidental spill or non-customary batch discharge, or pollutant which may include oxygen demanding pollutants (BOD, etc.) released at a flow rate and/or pollutant concentration which may cause an interference to the POTW, pass-through to the receiving stream, sludge contamination or endangerment to the POTW personnel, or in any other way violate the control authority's regulations, local limits, or permit conditions, as defined in 40 CFR Part 403.8(f)(2)(vi). 
Standard industrial classification (SIC) code: As defined by the U.S. Department of Commerce Bureau of the Census and further defined in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual issued by the United States Office of Management and Budget. 
Storm sewer: A public sewer which carries stormwater, surface water and drainage, into which domestic wastewater or industrial wastes are not intentionally passed. 
Stormwater: Any flow occurring during or following any form of natural precipitation, and resulting from such precipitation, including snowmelt. 
TCEQ: The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality, any duly authorized official of said agency, or any successor agency. 
Total suspended solids or TSS: Solids measured in mg/L that float on the surface or, are in suspension in water, wastewater, or other liquids, and which are removable by a laboratory filtration device. 
TPDES: The Texas Pollutant Discharge Elimination System, or the state regulatory authority to administer the NPDES program and requirements of certain sections of the federal Clean Water Act. 
Unpolluted wastewater: Stormwater, unpolluted groundwater, roof runoff, downspouts, yard fountains, pools, cooling water, drainage, or water which does not contain pollutants. 
USC: The United States Code. 
USEPA: The United States Environmental Protection Agency. 
Wastewater: A combination of the liquid and water-carried wastes from residential dwellings, commercial buildings, industrial and manufacturing facilities, and institutions, whether treated or untreated, which are contributed to the POTW. 
Wastewater service charge: The charge on all users of the public sewer system whose wastes do not exceed in strength the concentration values established as representative of normal wastewater. 
Watercourse: A natural or man-made channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-114. - Discharge prohibitions and limitations. 
(a)  General discharge prohibitions. 
(1)  No person shall discharge into public sewers: 
a.  Any substance capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or excessive loading, interference or pass-through to the POTW. 
b.  Solid or viscous substances, or substances which may become solid or viscous at temperatures between zero and 40 degrees Centigrade in amounts capable of causing obstruction of the flow in the POTW. 
c.  Wastewater which imparts color which cannot be removed by the treatment process, such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions, which consequently imparts color to the treatment plant's effluent, thereby violating the POTW's discharge permit. 
d.  Petroleum oil, non-biodegradable cutting oil, or products of mineral oil origin in amounts that will cause interference or pass through. 
e.  Gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil and other flammable or explosive liquids which can cause the explosion meter to read ten percent of the lower explosive level (LEL). 
f.  Pollutants which create a fire or explosion hazard in the POTW, including, but not limited to, wastestreams with a closed cup flashpoint of less than 60 degrees Centigrade (140 degrees Fahrenheit) as measured by the test method specified in 40 CFR 261.21. 
g.  Any pollutant, including oxygen demanding pollutants, (BOD, etc.) released at a flow rate and/or pollutant concentration which will cause interference with the POTW. 
h.  Hazardous waste as defined by the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act is prohibited from entering the POTW. 
i.  Slug loads are prohibited. 
j.  Any radioactive wastes or isotopes except in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations. 
k.  Medical wastes, unless otherwise authorized by the control authority. 
l.  Unpolluted stormwater, surface water, unpolluted groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage or other unpolluted drainage. In compliance with state and federal statutes, the control authority may, in writing, designate storm sewers and other watercourses into which unpolluted drainage may be discharged. 
(b)  General discharge limitations. 
(1)  No waste or wastewater discharged to the public sewer shall: 
a.  Have a pH lower than 6.0 or higher than 9.0 standard units or possess any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment and/or personnel at the POTW. 
b.  Have a temperature which will cause inhibition of biological activity at the POTW resulting in interference, but in no case contain heat in such quantity as to cause the temperature at the POTW treatment plant to exceed 40°C (104°F). 
c.  Contain grease or oil in concentrations greater than 200 mg/L or in such a quantity as to clog the sewer, and/or overload skimming and grease handling equipment. 
d.  Contain pollutants which may result in the presence of toxic gases, vapors, or fumes within the POTW in a quantity that may cause acute worker health and safety problems. 
e.  Contain concentrations of TSS and/or BOD, determined by the control authority to be detrimental to the POTW. 
f.  Contain garbage, unless it is shredded to a degree that all particles can be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers. 
g.  No person shall discharge to the public sewers any waste which by itself or by interaction with other waste shall: 
1.  Injure or interfere with POTW processes or facilities; 
2.  Constitute a hazard to humans or animals; 
3.  Pass through to receiving waters of the POTW effluent; 
4.  Cause toxicity in the receiving waters; 
5.  Render the sludge from the POTW unfit for use or disposal; and/or 
6.  Cause the POTW to violate its NPDES permit. 
(c)  Specific pollutant limitations. 
(1)  At the discharge point to the public sewer system, no wastewater shall contain concentrations of pollutants greater than the following specified limits: 
Heavy Metals 	Daily Maximum Discharge Limits (mg/L) 
Arsenic 	0.78 
Cadmium 	0.43 
Chromium (Total) 	8.41 
Copper 	1.15 
Cyanide 	0.50 
Lead 	3.71 
Mercury 	0.001 
Nickel 	8.37 
Selenium 	0.60 
Silver 	0.50 
Zinc 	1.58 
 
(2)  Industries subject to federal categorical standards as found in 40 CFR Chapter I, Subchapter N are required to meet the categorical limits at end of regulated processes and the applicable local limits at end of pipe. 
a.  Where a categorical pretreatment standard is expressed only in terms of either the mass or the concentration of a pollutant in wastewater, the control authority may impose equivalent concentration or mass limits in accordance with 40 CFR 403.6(c). 
b.  When wastewater subject to a categorical pretreatment standard is mixed with wastewater not regulated by the same standard, the control authority shall impose alternate limit using the combined wastestream formula in 40 CFR 403.6(e). 
c.  A user may obtain a variance from a categorical pretreatment standard if the user can prove, pursuant to the procedural and substantive provisions in 40 CFR 403.13, that factors relating to its discharge are fundamentally different from the factors considered by EPA, when developing the categorical pretreatment standard. 
d.  A user may obtain a net gross adjustment to a categorical standard in accordance with 40 CFR 403.15. 
(3)  Based on treatment technology and environmental standards, specific numerical limits may be developed for any pollutant and incorporated into an industrial waste permit. Permit specific numerical limits are fully enforceable under this article. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-115. - Approval of wastewater discharge conditions for new and existing sources. 
(a)  General acceptance. 
(1)  If discharge or proposed discharge to public sewers violates any provision of section 16-114, the control authority shall require: 
a.  Pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewer system; and 
b.  Control over the quantities and rates of discharge. 
(2)  The control authority may reject any waste, which does not meet the requirements of subsection (a)(1) of this section. 
(3)  The control authority may require any information from an industrial user necessary to determine the characteristics of the user's wastewater discharge prior to the commencement of such discharge to the POTW. 
(4)  The control authority may deny or condition new or increased contributions. 
(b)  For new sources. 
(1)  The industrial user shall consult with the control authority concerning the type(s), concentration and volume of industrial waste proposed for discharge. Conditional approval as to the general requirements must be obtained from the control authority. 
(2)  Design calculations, plans, specifications, and other pertinent information relating to proposed industrial waste pretreatment or processing facilities shall be submitted to the control authority for approval prior to start of construction if the effluent from such facilities is to be discharged into the public sewers. 
(3)  Where required by the control authority, the industrial user shall modify or eliminate wastes that are harmful to the structures, process, or operations of the sewage works; the industrial user shall provide, at its expense, such preliminary treatment or processing facilities as may be determined necessary to render its wastes acceptable for admission to the public sewer. 
(4)  Review and acceptance of the conditions for new sources by the control authority shall be obtained prior to the proposed discharge into the public sewers of any wastes and waters having the following: 
a.  A five-day 20 degrees C biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) greater than 240 mg/L; 
b.  Total suspended solids (TSS) greater than 240 mg/L; 
c.  Substances prohibited or limited by section 16-114. 
(c)  For existing sources. 
(1)  At the discretion of the control authority, existing sources may be required to meet the review and acceptance conditions for new sources under subsection (b) of this section. 
(2)  Within a specified time limit following written notice by the control authority, the industrial user will submit a compliance plan, which will achieve acceptable discharge conditions. 
(3)  If an acceptable plan has not been submitted within the specified time limit, the control authority may prescribe a suitable compliance plan. 
(4)  If the industrial user fails to fulfill the conditions of the prescribed compliance plan, he shall be in violation of this article and subject to penalties and enforcement actions as described in sections 16-123 and 16-137 of this article. 
(d)  Pretreatment provisions. 
(1)  If pretreatment or control is required, the control authority shall review and either accept or deny the proposed design and installation of equipment and processes. Acceptance of a proposed pretreatment plan by the control authority shall not relieve the industrial user of responsibility and/or liability for failure of that pretreatment to achieve acceptable discharge. 
(2)  The design and installation of equipment and processes must conform to all applicable statutes, codes, ordinances and other laws. 
(3)  Any industrial user responsible for discharges requiring pretreatment, flow-equalizing, or other facilities shall provide and maintain the facilities in effective operating condition at its own expense. 
(4)  Persons discharging industrial wastes, which exhibit none of the characteristics of wastes prohibited in this article other than excessive BOD or TSS, may be required to pretreat the industrial wastes to meet the requirements of "normal domestic sewage". 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-116. - General discharge restrictions. 
(a)  No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, any unpolluted wastewater into sanitary sewers if a storm sewer is available, except in cases where there is an existing facility erected prior to the enactment of this article, in accordance with plans approved by the city until required to alleviate such condition by the city after reasonable notice. 
If a storm sewer is not available, unpolluted wastewater may be discharged into the sanitary sewer by an indirect connection whereby such discharge is cooled, if required, and flows into the sanitary sewer at a rate not in excess of three gallons per minute. 
(b)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any pollutants into or adjacent to any waters or any area within the jurisdiction of the city. 
(c)  In cases where, in the opinion of the control authority, the character of the sewage from any manufacturer or industrial plant, building or other premises is such that it will damage the sewer system or cannot be treated satisfactorily in the system, the city shall have the right to require such waste be disposed of otherwise, in accordance with all applicable regulations, and prevent it from entering the city's system. 
(d)  No person shall discharge industrial waste, interceptor waste, or any other waste determined by the control authority as not acceptable, into the public sewer from a vehicle, tank truck, portable tank or other container used for transportation of industrial waste. 
(e)  No person shall discharge domestic wastewater or septage from a tank truck, portable tank or other container used for transportation of waste, into a public sewer without written permission from the city as provided in this Code regulating the generation, transportation and disposal of such waste, and then only at a designated discharge point. The control authority reserves the right to refuse any such discharge. 
(f)  No person shall discharge wastewater or industrial waste into a sewer appurtenance intended for maintenance, including but not limited to, a manhole or clean-out connection or inspection port without written permission from the control authority. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-117. - Dilution prohibition as substitute for treatment. 
Except where expressly authorized to do so by an applicable categorical pretreatment standard, no industrial user shall ever increase the use of process water or in any other way attempt to dilute a discharge as a partial or complete substitute for adequate treatment to achieve compliance with a categorical pretreatment standard. Although wastestreams may be mixed prior to discharge to the POTW, no industrial user may dilute for the express purpose of compliance with local discharge limits. 
The control authority may impose mass limitations on industrial users, which are using dilution to meet applicable pretreatment standards or requirements, or in other cases where the imposition of mass limitations is appropriate, in accordance with 40 CFR 403.6(d). 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-118. - Accidental or slug discharges. 
(a)  Spill containment/slug control. The control authority may require spill containment or slug control measures for storage and use of any substance it deems a potential threat to the collection and treatment system or the environment should such substance be accidentally discharged. Such spill containment or slug control measures shall be provided and maintained at the owner's or user's own cost and expense. Detailed plans showing facilities and operating procedures to provide this protection shall be submitted to the city for review, and shall be approved by the city before construction of the facility. All existing users shall complete such a plan as required by the control authority. At the discretion of the control authority, industrial users may be required to submit accidental discharge or slug control procedures prior to commencing contribution to the POTW. Review and approval of such plans and operating procedures shall not relieve the user from the responsibility to modify the facility as necessary to meet the requirements of this article. 
(b)  Industrial pretreatment system upset and/or bypass. Upsets and/or bypasses of industrial pretreatment systems shall be subject to the provisions of the V.T.C.A., Water Code § 7.251 and 40 CFR Part 403.17 respectively. A violation of pretreatment standards or V.T.C.A., Water Code Ch. 26, that would otherwise be found in violation of this article, the industrial waste permit or other regulatory requirements, may be found not in violation should the violation have been caused solely by an act of God, war, strike, riot or other catastrophe. Bypass of a pretreatment system is prohibited except under the conditions stated in 40 CFR Part 403.17(d). 
(c)  Notification of potential problem. In the case of an accidental discharge, slug discharge, upset or unavoidable bypass, it is the responsibility of the user to notify the control authority within 24 hours of the incident. The notification shall include location of the discharge, type of waste, concentration and volume, and corrective action. Within five days following an accidental discharge, the user shall submit to the control authority a detailed written report describing the cause of the discharge and the measures to be taken by the user to prevent similar future occurrences. Such notification shall not relieve the user of any expense, loss, damage or other liability which may be incurred as a result of damage to the POTW, fish kills, or any other damage to persons or property, nor shall such notification relieve the user of any fines, civil penalties, or other liability which may be imposed by this article or other applicable law. 
(d)  Notice to employees. A notice shall be permanently posted on the user's bulletin board or other prominent place advising employees who to call in the event of an accidental or slug discharge. Employers shall insure that all employees who may cause or suffer such an accidental or slug discharge to occur are advised of the emergency notification procedure. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-119. - Volume of waste. 
When water is contained in a product, evaporated, or discharged as unpolluted waste to surface drainage, an application may be made for a reduction in the volume of waste discharged to the public sewer. Supporting data, satisfactory to the control authority, must be furnished. 
This data shall include a flow diagram, destination of the water supply and/or wastes, supported by sub-metering data installed on said process piping at the expense of the user. Any metering device used to measure actual sewage flow must meet all requirements set forth by and be approved by the control authority. The design and installation costs are the responsibility of the user. Upon installation and acceptance, the control authority shall assume ownership of and maintain any such device in proper working condition to accurately measure such flow. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-120. - Control of admissible wastes. 
Any person desiring to deposit or discharge any industrial waste into the public sewers of the city or any sewer connected therewith, or who is now so doing may require an industrial waste permit (including both new and existing connections). 
(1)  The control authority shall have the legal authority and responsibility through any interjurisdictional pretreatment agreement to perform the technical and administrative activities necessary for implementation of a pretreatment program. 
(2)  Any person discharging or desiring to discharge an industrial waste mixture into the sanitary sewer of the city or any sewer connected therewith, shall be required to provide and maintain in a suitably accessible position on the permittee's premises, or such premises occupied by him, an inspection port or manhole near the outlet of each sewer, drain, pipe, channel or connection which communicates with the sewer or sewer works of the city or any sewer connected therewith. Each such manhole or inspection port shall be of such design and construction which will prevent infiltration by ground and surface waters, and shall be so maintained by the user discharging wastes so that any authorized representative of the city may readily and safely measure the volume and obtain samples of the flow at all times. Plans for construction of the control manholes or inspection port, including such flow measuring devices as may be required shall be reviewed, and approved by the control authority. The control authority also reserves the right to require installation of other monitoring equipment if deemed necessary. 
(3)  The control authority shall verify prior to discharge that wastes authorized to be discharged will receive, if needed, suitable pretreatment within the provisions of law, regulations, ordinances, rules and orders of federal, state and local governments. 
(4)  The control authority may request material safety data sheets for chemicals stored or used at a facility. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-121. - Industrial waste permits. 
No significant industrial user shall discharge industrial waste into the sanitary sewer without obtaining and maintaining a valid permit from the control authority. The control authority may require other users to obtain a discharge permit as necessary to carry out the purposes of this article. 
(1)  Conditions stipulated in the industrial waste permits shall be based on plans and specifications of pretreatment facilities, on-site inspections, and industrial waste permit applications. 
(2)  Industrial waste permits may dictate: 
a.  Discharge limits, including BMPs if applicable; 
b.  Self-monitoring requirements; 
c.  Reporting requirements; 
d.  Notification and record keeping requirements (five years, including BMPs), including an identification of the pollutants to be monitored; 
e.  Sampling locations, frequency and sample type; and 
f.  Other conditions as deemed appropriate by the control authority to ensure compliance with this ordinance including, but not limited to, a statement of applicable civil and criminal penalties and slug discharge control requirements (if necessary). 
(3)  The control authority shall issue a permit if it is determined that: 
a.  Pretreatment facilities are adequate for efficient treatment of discharged waste; 
b.  Applicant is not discharging waste in violation of this article; and 
c.  Applicant is in compliance with applicable federal, state and local laws and regulations. 
(4)  The control authority may issue a compliance schedule in conjunction with an industrial waste permit if conditions in subsections 16-121(3)a—c above, are not being met. The compliance schedule shall contain deadlines for the commencement and completion of major events leading to compliance with applicable requirements. 
(5)  It is the responsibility of the industrial user to notify the control authority prior to any change in process, change in character or quantity of wastewater, change in ownership or change in signatory authority. These changes may require issuance of a new permit. 
(6)  Permits shall not be transferred except with the express written permission of the control authority. Upon transfer of ownership the permittee must provide a copy of the existing permit to the new owner. 
(7)  Permits shall be valid for a period not to exceed three years from the date of issuance. They shall be reviewed annually, but may be modified at any time, as the control authority deems necessary. At least 60 days prior to permit expiration or within a minimum of 60 days from promulgation of a pretreatment standard or being designated as an SIU, an application for permit renewal must be received by the control authority. 
(8)  Permits may be revoked if the requirements for self-monitoring, reporting, compliance and any other requirement set forth in the permit and this article are not being met. The industrial user must immediately cease discharge upon permit revocation. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-122. - Inspections, sampling and testing. 
(a)  The control authority shall randomly sample and analyze the effluent from industrial users and conduct surveillance activities in order to identify, independent of information supplied by industrial users, occasional and continuing noncompliance with pretreatment and pollution control standards. 
(b)  The control authority shall inspect and sample the effluent from each significant industrial user at least once a year and evaluate, within one year of being designated as significant, whether each significant industrial user needs a plan or other action to control slug discharges in accordance with 40 CFR 403.8(f)(2)(vi). The results of these activities shall be retained by the CA and be available to the approval authority upon request. If the SIU is required to develop a slug discharge control plan, or other action, the CA is required to specify the appropriate requirements in the IU permit. 
(c)  The control authority shall investigate instances of noncompliance with pretreatment standards or pollution control requirements, as indicated in required reports, analytical results, inspections and surveillance activities. 
(d)  Collection of information by the control authority shall be performed with sufficient care to produce evidence admissible in enforcement proceedings or in judicial actions. 
(e)  All sampling and analysis shall be performed in accordance with procedures established by the EPA administrator pursuant to Section 304(h) of the Clean Water Act and 40 CFR Part 136 and amendments thereto. Analyses shall be performed on flow weighted samples, where feasible, taken at the inspection port provided or other control point authorized by the control authority. 
(f)  BOD and TSS shall be determined from composite sampling, except to detect unauthorized discharges. 
(g)  The city may select an independent firm or laboratory to determine flow, BOD, TSS and/or other wastewater constituents. Chain of custody procedures shall be followed. 
(h)  The city is entitled to select the time of sampling. 
(i)  Samples shall be taken at six-month intervals (at minimum) to establish the BOD and TSS of the industrial waste for billing purposes, or at such intervals determined by the control authority as necessary to maintain control over the discharge. 
(j)  Sampling and testing of industrial waste streams shall be conducted for the purpose of monitoring compliance with federal, state and local discharge regulations. The control authority shall determine the frequency of sampling and the pollutants (unless categorical) to be monitored for each industrial user. 
(k)  The control authority shall maintain records of all information resulting from monitoring activities required by 40 CFR Part 403, including documentation associated with BMPs. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-123. - Noncompliance notification and procedure. 
(a)  Each noncompliance with local, state or federal regulations may result in the person receiving a verbal notice and/or written notice of violation. A written notice of violation shall require that the person respond, in writing, to the control authority within 15 working days from the date of the notice of violation. 
(b)  In addition to the notice set forth in subsection (a), noncompliance may result in enforcement actions by the control authority, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Issuance of a warning citation; 
(2)  Issuance of a citation; 
(3)  Setting a compliance meeting; 
(4)  Issuance of a compliance schedule; 
(5)  Termination of water and/or sewer service; 
(6)  Revocation of an industrial waste permit; 
(7)  Administrative orders including consent orders, compliance orders, and cease and desist orders; and 
(8)  Any other supplemental enforcement actions as noted in the control authority's enforcement response plan, i.e., show cause hearings. 
The control authority shall determine the level of enforcement needed to promote compliance. 
(c)  A compliance schedule shall specify deadlines for initiating and completing actions needed to remedy a noncompliance. Failure to meet the deadlines specified in a compliance schedule or continued noncompliance after the final compliance date may result in escalation of enforcement actions by the control authority. 
Compliance schedules developed for meeting categorical pretreatment standards shall comply with the requirements of 40 CFR 403.12(c), including required BMPs. 
(d)  No action by the control authority shall relieve an industrial user from being published for significant noncompliance as described in section 16-129 of this article. 
(e)  The control authority, may by use of all legal means available, stop an actual or threatened discharge by verbal order to cease discharge if, in the opinion of the control authority, the discharge presents or may present an imminent or substantial endangerment to the health or welfare of persons or the environment or which may be in violation of local, state or federal regulations. 
If the person does not voluntarily comply with the order to cease discharge, the control authority shall take such steps as deemed necessary, including, but not limited to, severance of the sewer connections and/or suspension of water service, to prevent or minimize damage to the POTW system or environment or endangerment to the public. Prior to service being restored, the person must demonstrate to the control authority that permanent corrective measures have been taken to prevent reoccurrence of the offense. Any cost incurred by the control authority for sampling, analysis, assessment or remediation may be recovered from the person, or its authorized representative. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-124. - Reporting requirements. 
(a)  Initial compliance reports. 
(1)  All industrial users, including new sources that are subject to categorical pretreatment standards must submit baseline monitoring reports (BMRs) to the control authority in accordance with 40 CFR 403.12(b). The BMR includes: 
a.  Identifying information; 
b.  Other environmental permits held; 
c.  Description of operations; 
d.  Flow measurements; 
e.  Measurement of pollutants, and documentation to demonstrate compliance with a BMP where a required BMP or pollution prevention (P2) alternative is part of the categorical standard; and 
f.  Certification of compliance with pretreatment standards. 
(2)  Within 90 days following the commencement of the contribution of wastewater into the POTW, any industrial user classified as a regulated categorical industrial user, and therefore subject to federal categorical pretreatment standards, shall submit to the control authority a 90-day compliance report in accordance with 40 CFR 403.12(d). The 90-day compliance report includes: 
a.  Flow measurements; 
b.  Measurement of pollutants, and documentation to demonstrate compliance with a BMP where a required BMP or pollution prevention (P2) alternative is part of the categorical standard; and 
c.  Certification of compliance with pretreatment standards. 
(3)  Significant industrial users not classified as categorical industrial users may, at the discretion of the control authority, be required to submit a baseline monitoring report and/or a 90-day compliance report. 
(b)  Periodic compliance reports. 
(1)  Categorical standard industries subject to a pretreatment standard, after the compliance date of such pretreatment standard or, in the case of new sources, after commencement of the discharge to the POTW, shall submit a semi-annual compliance report to the control authority in accordance with 40 CFR 403.12(e). 
(2)  Significant non-categorical industrial users are required to submit a semi-annual compliance report to the control authority in accordance with 40 CFR 403.12(h). 
(3)  Semi-annual compliance reports required under subsections (b)(1) and (b)(2) of this section shall be based on sampling and analytical data collected during the period covered by the report by both the control authority and the industrial user if self monitoring is performed. Sampling and analytical data shall be representative of the conditions occurring during the reporting period. The CA shall require the number of grab samples necessary to assess and assure compliance by IUs with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements. Additionally, categorical industrial users shall submit documentation to demonstrate compliance with a BMP where required BMPs or pollution prevention alternatives are part of the categorical standard. Semi-annual compliance reports must be submitted to the control authority each year by July 15th for the January through June reporting period, and by January 15th for the July through December reporting period. 
(c)  Self-monitoring reports. 
(1)  Categorical industrial users shall perform self-monitoring sampling and analysis of the regulated process wastestream at a frequency stipulated by the industrial waste permit. Additionally, categorical industrial users shall submit documentation to demonstrate compliance with a BMP where required BMPs or pollution prevention alternatives are part of the categorical standard. 
(2)  Categorical industrial users and significant industrial users may be required to perform self-monitoring on non-categorical wastestreams, should the control authority deem it necessary. Categorical and significant industrial users are required to report data obtained through appropriate sampling and analysis performed during the period covered by the report which data are representative of conditions occurring during the reporting period. 
(3)  Self-monitoring samples shall be collected, preserved and analyzed in accordance with 40 CFR Part 136. 
(4)  For each self-monitoring sample, the industrial user shall submit, and maintain for a minimum period of five years, an industrial self-monitoring sampling report which shall include: 
a.  The date, exact place, sampling method, preservation method, times of sampling and the name of the person(s) who collected the samples; 
b.  The dates the analyses were performed; 
c.  Name of the person(s) who performed the analyses; 
d.  The analytical techniques/method used; and appropriate QA/QC documentation; and 
e.  The results of the analyses. 
f.  If an industry monitors more frequently, at the designated sampling port, than required by the permit using approved test methods, they must submit those sample results along with the required self-monitoring report. 
g.  All samples collected must be representative of the discharge (over the course of the discharge) according to 40 CFR §§ 403.12(g)(1), (3), (4) and (5). 
(5)  For categorical industrial users, at least once during each semi-annual compliance reporting period, self-monitoring samples shall be analyzed for all federally regulated parameters. 
(6)  If self-monitoring indicates a violation, the industrial user shall notify the control authority within 24 hours of receiving the results. The industrial user shall also repeat the sampling and analysis and submit the results of the repeat analysis within 30 days after becoming aware of the violation. For industrial users required to self monitor each month, the next month's self-monitoring may be used as the repeat sampling so long as the sample is analyzed for the violating parameter and the 30-day submission deadline is observed. Similarly, if the control authority is sampling in lieu of the industrial user, the CA will repeat sampling within 30 days. 
(d)  Signatory authority. All initial and periodic compliance reports and all self-monitoring sampling reports must be signed by an authorized official of the industrial user in accordance with 40 CFR Part 403.12(l). The authorized official may designate a representative, in writing, to the control authority. The authorization must specify either an individual or a position having responsibility for the overall operation of the facility from which the industrial discharge originates, or having overall responsibility for environmental matters for the industrial user. If the authorization becomes invalid because of changes in responsibilities or personnel, a new written authorization must be submitted to the control authority prior to or along with any report being signed and submitted by the new representative. A change in signatory authority shall not negate existing enforcement action. 
(e)  Certification statements. All initial and periodic compliance reports, self-monitoring sampling reports and the industrial waste permit application must include this statement: 
 "I certify under penalty of law that this document and all attachments were prepared under my direction or supervised in accordance with a system designed to assure that qualified personnel properly gather and evaluate the information submitted. Based on my inquiry of the person or persons who manage the system, or those persons directly responsible for gathering the information, the information submitted is, to the best of my knowledge and belief, true, accurate and complete. I am aware that there are significant penalties for submitting false information including the possibility of fine and imprisonment for knowing violations." 
(f)  Report on changed conditions. All industrial users shall promptly notify the control authority in advance of any substantial change in volume or character of pollutants in their discharge, or of any changes at its facility affecting the potential for a slug discharge [§ 403.8(f)(2)(vi)]. 
(g)  Discharge of hazardous waste. Hazardous waste as defined by the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act is prohibited from entering the POTW. An industrial user shall notify the control authority, the EPA regional waste management division director, and the state hazardous waste authorities, in writing, of any discharge into the POTW of a substance, which, if otherwise disposed of, would be a hazardous waste under 40 CFR Part 261, in accordance with 40 CFR 403.12(p). 
(h)  Fraud and false statements. The reports and other documents required to be submitted or maintained under this section shall be subject to: 
(1)  The provisions of 18 U.S.C. Section 1001 relating to fraud and false statements; 
(2)  The provisions of Section 309(c)(4) of the Clean Water Act, as amended, governing false statements, representation, or certification; 
(3)  The provisions of Section 309(c)(6) of the Clean Water Act regarding responsible corporate offices; and 
(4)  Section 16-134 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-125. - Industrial waste surcharge. 
(a)  Industrial wastes which exhibit none of the characteristics of wastes prohibited previously but having a BOD or TSS concentration in excess of "normal domestic sewage" as defined in section 16-113, may require pretreatment; however, such wastes may be accepted for treatment if the following requirements are met: 
(1)  The waste will not cause damage to the collection and treatment facility; 
(2)  The waste will not impair the treatment process; 
(3)  The waste will not cause the POTW to violate its NPDES permit; and 
(4)  The donor of the waste pays the sewer service charge and industrial waste surcharge. 
(b)  The basis for surcharge on industrial waste is capital and operating costs and is an assessment over and above published water and sewer rates. The surcharge shall be calculated for billing purposes utilizing the following formula: 
S.C. 	= 	V [(A)(BOD-240) + B(TSS-240)] 
S.C. 	= 	Surcharge in dollars for time related to volume 
V 	= 	Volume in 1,000 gallons based on metered water unless an approved effluent metering device is installed 
BOD 	= 	5 days @ 20 degrees C. of industrial waste (mg/L) 
TSS 	= 	Total Suspended Solids of industrial waste (mg/L) 
A 	= 	Capital and operating cost for removal of BOD per mg/L 
B 	= 	Capital and operating cost for removal of TSS per mg/L 
Rates for A and B will be set periodically by action of the city council 
 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-126. - Requirements for interceptors. 
All requirements shall be in accordance with the provisions of chapter 16, article II, sections 16-26— 16-110, of this chapter regulating the transportation and discharge of such waste as it now exists or as hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-127. - Requirements for building sewers. 
(a)  Any user responsible for discharge through a building sewer carrying industrial waste shall, at such user's own expense and as required by the control authority: 
(1)  Install an accessible and safely located control manhole; 
(2)  Install meters and other appurtenances to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the waste as may be required; and 
(3)  Maintain the equipment and facilities. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-128. - Requirements for dental offices. 
All existing and new dental users subject to the dental office category regulation as codified in 40 CFR Part 441 must comply with the requirements of the regulation. Compliance reports must be completed and submitted to the CA in the required timeframe. 
( 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20) 
Editor's note— 0220-20-ORD amended art. III in its entirety and added new provisions as § 16-128 and renumbering existing §§ 16-128—16-137 as §§ 16-129—16-138, as herein set out.  
Sec. 16-129. - Public notice of significant noncompliance. 
A notice shall be placed in a newspaper of general circulation that provides meaningful notice within the jurisdiction(s) served by the POTW each year as required by 40 CFR 403.8(f)(2)(viii), as it now exists or as hereafter amended for significant noncompliance. The notification shall include the industry name and address plus a description of said violation(s). The notification shall be for a designated 12-month period in which any IUs were in SNC with applicable pretreatment requirements. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-130. - Charges and fees. 
(a)  The city may adopt charges and fees, which may include: 
(1)  Fees for reimbursement of costs of setting up and operating the city's pretreatment program; 
(2)  Fees for monitoring, inspection and surveillance procedures; 
(3)  Fees for reviewing accidental discharge procedures and construction; 
(4)  Fees for permit applications; 
(5)  Fees for filing appeals; 
(6)  Fees for industrial waste surcharges as provided for in section 16-125; 
(7)  Cost for laboratory analyses of industrial discharge; and 
(8)  Other fees as the city may deem necessary to carry out the requirements contained herein. 
(b)  These fees relate solely to the matters covered by this article and are separate from all other applicable fees chargeable by the city. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-131. - Billing. 
Industrial waste surcharge provided for in this article shall be included as a separate item on the regular bill for water and sewer charges and shall be paid monthly in accordance with the existing billing practices of the city. Surcharges shall be paid at the same time that the water, sewer, and sanitation charges of the person becomes due and payment for water and sanitation services shall not be accepted without payment also of the sewer service charges and industrial waste surcharges. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-132. - Failure to pay bills. 
Failure to pay fees and monthly bills for water, sanitary sewer service or industrial waste surcharge when due shall be sufficient cause to disconnect any and all services to the water and/or sanitary sewer of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-133. - Access to industrial user records.
