(a)  The control authority and the approval authority shall have access to, and the right to inspect and copy, any and all industrial user records which pertain to that industry's discharge to the POTW, disposal and/or generation of hazardous waste and discharges into the environment. The industrial user shall be required to retain records of all information resulting from any monitoring or reporting activity required by these regulations for a minimum of five years. This period of retention shall be extended during the course of any unresolved litigation regarding the industrial user or POTW or when requested by the approval authority. 
(b)  The constituents and characteristics of wastewater discharged by an industrial user shall not be considered confidential and shall be available to the public without restriction. Other information obtained from reports, questionnaires, permit applications, permits, monitoring programs and inspections shall be available to the public without restriction unless the user specifically requests, in writing, at the time the information is known to be obtained by the control authority that the information is to be considered confidential. Information submitted to the control authority by the industrial user shall be stamped "Confidential Information" on each page containing such information that the industrial user wishes to be held confidential. If a claim of confidentiality is asserted, the control authority shall determine if such information may be held confidential in accordance with 40 CFR Part 2 (Public Information). If the industrial user does not claim the information as confidential at the time the control authority obtains the information, it will be available to the public without further notice. 
(c)  The city shall require of all non-domestic users, information needed to develop a systematic program according to the pretreatment requirements. The information must be available to the control authority for inspection and reproduction. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-134. - Falsifying information. 
Any person who knowingly makes any false statements, representation or certification in any application, notice, record, report, plan or other document filed or required to be maintained pursuant to this article, or industrial waste permit, or who falsifies, tampers with, or knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device or method required under this article, shall be punished by a fine of no more than $10,000.00 and may be subject to prosecution. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-135. - Protection from damage. 
No unauthorized person shall intentionally, knowingly, recklessly or by criminal negligence, cause damage to, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or equipment, which is part of the POTW. Any person violating this provision shall be subject to prosecution. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-136. - Power to enter property. 
(a)  The control authority and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification are entitled to: 
(1)  Enter any public or private property at any reasonable time for the purpose of enforcing this article; and 
(2)  Enter all private property through which the city holds an easement for the purpose of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, maintenance or repair. 
(b)  All activities conducted under this authority shall be in full accordance with all applicable terms, rules and regulations pertaining to safety and security. 
(c)  If the control authority has been refused access to a building, structure, or property, or any part thereof, and is able to demonstrate probable cause to believe that there may be a violation of this article, or that there is a need to inspect and/or sample as part of a routine inspection and sampling program of the city designed to verify compliance with this article or any permit or order issued hereunder, or to protect the overall public health, safety welfare of the community, then the control authority may seek issuance of a search warrant from the municipal court of the City of Lewisville, Denton County, Texas. 
(d)  No person acting under authority of this provision may inquire into any area not having direct or potential impact on the kind and source of a discharge to the public sewer system, disposal and/or generation of hazardous waste and discharges into the environment, except as provided in section 16-133. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-137. - Legal action. 
If any person discharges, permits or causes to be discharged sewage, industrial waste or other wastes in violation of V.T.C.A., Water Code Ch. 26 or into the POTW contrary to the provisions of this article, state requirements, federal pretreatment requirements, or any order of the city, the city attorney may commence an action for appropriate legal and/or equitable relief, including injunctive relief, in the district court of Denton County, Texas. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Sec. 16-138. - Penalties. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if the person intentionally, knowingly, recklessly or by criminal negligence violates any provision of this article or any order or permit issued hereunder, and upon conviction, shall be deemed guilty of a class C misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $2,000.00, and each day that such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage occasioned by the city by reason of such violation. In addition to the penalties provided herein, the city may recover reasonable attorney's fees, court costs, court reporter's fees and other expenses of litigation by appropriate suit at law against the person found to have violated this article or the orders, rules, regulations and permits issued hereunder. 
(c)  The control authority is further authorized to prosecute and seek all criminal and civil remedies in the various courts as set forth by the Texas Water Code. 
(d)  Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be punished upon conviction by a fine not to exceed $2,000.00 for each offense, and each and every day such violation shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. In no case shall a fine be recommended which is less than the economic benefit realized by the industry for violation of pretreatment standards, in accordance with the U.S. EPA's Guidance Manual for Calculation of Economic Benefit of Noncompliance with Pretreatment Standards: 1990. 
(Ord. No. 3734-01-2010 , § I, 1-4-10; 0220-20-ORD , § 1(Exh. A), 6-1-20)  
Secs. 16-139—16-200. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - WATER AND SEWER EXTENSIONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Charter reference— Power to regulate use of streets, § 2.01. 
Cross reference— Plumbing standards, § 4-111 et seq.; permits for public works construction in the rights-of-way and easement required, § 6-61 et seq.; erosion control requirements, § 6-331 et seq.; requirements for improvements on land served by substandard public improvements, § 6-436 et seq. 
 
Sec. 16-201. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Charge shall mean a charge made against the consumer or property owner to pay for the cost of installation or extension of water and sanitary sewer mains as provided for in this article. 
Consumer shall mean the actual user of water from a city water main or of a sanitary sewer connection. 
Frontage shall be determined by the side of the lot on which the legal address is located. 
Off-site improvements shall mean water or sewer main improvements totally outside of a tract of land to be subdivided and developed for resale. 
On-site improvements shall mean water or sewer main improvements totally within or adjacent to a tract of land to be subdivided and developed for resale. 
(Code 1990, § 2-4-1; Ord. No. 2089-2-96, § I, 2-5-96) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 16-202. - To individual property owners. 
(a)  Upon request of a property owner of a given lot or tract of land, accompanied by the payment of the charges due under this article, the city may extend all necessary sanitary sewer and water mains, including valves, hydrants, and appurtenances, the distance across the frontage necessary to provide the service for which application has been made. The owner to be served shall be required to pay the charges herein provided for. The owners of all intervening property served by the given main extensions shall be required to pay the charges provided for herein at such time as their property is connected to the mains thus laid. The applicant shall pay the charges on all property owned by him and which is served by the requested extension. 
(b)  Upon approval of the city, the property owner requesting extension of water and sewer mains to his property may extend the mains himself or have same done by a competent and reputable contractor. In this case, detailed construction plans for the improvements shall be drawn and approved by the city prior to any construction, and the construction shall be inspected and approved prior to final acceptance by the city. The sizes of the above mains shall be determined by the city. The total costs of extending the mains to and across the owner's property shall be borne solely by the owner, with the following exceptions: 
(1)  Upon approval and acceptance of the system by the city, on any mains larger than 12 inches, the city will refund to the owner the difference between the cost of the oversized main and the 12-inch main if the size which exceeds 12 inches is not required to service the property. 
(2)  The city shall never be liable for any payment under this section unless a written agreement outlining the terms of payment is entered into between the city and the property owner. 
(Code 1990, § 2-4-3; Ord. No. 2089-2-96, § I, 2-5-96)  
Sec. 16-203. - To and within subdivisions. 
(a)  Extensions to subdivisions. Where extensions of water and sewer mains are required to serve property which has been subdivided or platted for development and resale, the costs of approach mains fronting on property not owned by the developer but required and necessary to connect property to be developed shall be borne solely by the developer. The sizes of all aforementioned mains shall be determined by the city. Refunds for main extensions will be as follows: 
(1)  Upon approval and acceptance of the system by the city, on any mains larger than 12-inch diameter, the city will pay, upon acceptance if funds are available, or will enter into an agreement with the developer, the amount being the difference between the cost of the oversized mains and the 12-inch diameter mains or the size which is over 12 inches and is in excess of the size required to develop the property adjacent to the main. 
(2)  The city will refund to the subdivider any charges received from applicants who desire to connect to the mains which have been extended with the total refund not to exceed the amount of the subdivider's cost of the off-site improvements. 
(3)  The maximum period of time for the reimbursement to the subdivider for the off-site mains shall not exceed ten years. 
(b)  Oversized mains within subdivisions. Developers of subdivisions shall bear the entire cost of water and sewer systems within or along the boundary of their subdivisions, except that on any mains larger than 12 inches the city will refund the difference between the cost of the oversized mains and the 12-inch main. Adequate size of such water and sewer mains shall be determined by the city, and in accordance with the city general development plan and its decision will be final. 
(c)  Liability of city. The city shall never be liable for any payment under this section unless a written agreement outlining the terms of payment is entered into between the city and the developer prior to the commencement of any construction in which the city will participate. 
(Code 1990, § 2-4-5; Ord. No. 2089-2-96, § I, 2-5-96)  
Sec. 16-203.5. - Extension program procedures. 
(a)  General requirements. 
(1)  The city council shall review all water and wastewater main extension requests on a case-by-case basis. For any request which meets all guidelines set forth in this procedure, council may choose to adopt a main extension ordinance. 
(2)  The city council shall determine all requirements for a site- specific main extension ordinance. 
(3)  Each project and associated ordinance must be approved by the city council; the ordinance shall be nontransferable, unless otherwise stated within the ordinance. 
(4)  The above requirements shall apply to situations which meet the following criteria: 
a.  The property to be serviced must be platted and the property owner must follow all general development guidelines. 
b.  All easements, dedication and public right-of-way necessary to construct the project must be acquired by the developer and filed by the city. The city may elect to use its power of condemnation to acquire the easement or right-of-way. 
c.  The extension program for reimbursement shall not include on-site projects. 
d.  Off-site projects which are less than 1,000 feet from an existing main shall not be included in the extension reimbursement program. If the site is greater than 1,000 feet from an existing main, the extension program may be utilized as authorized by the city council. 
e.  If the main has been determined as an impact fee related project, the project shall not be considered for extension reimbursement. 
(b)  Engineering requirements. 
(1)  The mains shall be extended through a development as determined by the city engineer for main extension to other developments. 
(2)  The engineering design must be performed by the developer or applicant. All engineering and construction standards must be as approved by the city and must meet the standard specifications for public works as outlined by NCTCOG. 
(3)  The developer must extend any water or sewer main at their expense from the proposed development or site to an existing main. 
(4)  The expense for the main within the development shall be that of the developer or applicant. Oversizing of water or wastewater mains will be performed by the city. The applicant will provide funding for the 12-inch portion of the project. 
(5)  If the oversizing cost is less than $5,000.00, the city may authorize the developer to construct the project with lump sum payment to the developer for the oversizing after approval and acceptance of the construction project. 
(c)  Reimbursement. 
(1)  City staff shall maintain records of expenditures for each project. Fees for inspection and management of the program shall be recovered by the city in accordance with the general development ordinance. 
(2)  The length of time for collection and distribution of funds shall not exceed ten years from the date of acceptance by the city. Reimbursement for off-site projects shall be based upon total acreage which can be serviced by the main, and is adjacent to the main, excluding rights-of-way, easements, or other public lands. 
(3)  Fees shall be assessed per acre. State or federal government properties which are not subject to development shall not be included in the acreage calculation. 
(4)  If a natural barrier exists in which service cannot be provided, that area shall not be included in the determination of the acreage. 
(5)  If a transmission main and distribution main are located along the frontage of the property, the fee will be based upon the distribution main only. 
(6)  Reimbursements will be made to the original signing party of the agreement, which is nontransferable, unless otherwise stated within the agreement. Reimbursements shall be made at six-month intervals beginning at the acceptance of the project and upon written request from the applicant. The amount reimbursed shall not exceed 100 percent of the actual construction cost, plus any interest imbedded, until the assessment is collected. The fixed interest rate shall be determined by the published prime rate in the Wall Street Journal at the time of the adoption of the ordinance. 
Extension fees shall be determined by the following calculation: 
Extension fee = Cost of project/total acreage + imbedded interest 
The imbedded interest shall be determined by the following calculation: 
Imbedded interest = Cost of project/total acreage × number of days outstanding × daily interest rate 
Monies will be collected from property owners adjacent to the main prior to the approval of the final plat, site plan, or building permit, whichever is first. The developer or applicant, as stated in the ordinance, shall request from the city any monies which have been collected pertaining to the project. 
A provision shall be made within the ordinance to allow for additional funds to be collected from the developer or applicant due to change order or improper design. 
(d)  City extension of water/sewer mains. 
(1)  The city, when acting in the capacity of a developer, may also extend certain water or sewer mains and utilize the main extension program to recover the cost of the main. 
(2)  The city may recover cost for the extension in the same manner as described herein for individuals and developers, except that the 1,000-foot minimum shall not apply. The city may collect fees for the extension regardless of the distance of the line to be constructed. 
(3)  When an extension is performed by the city, the collection of the fee shall not apply to existing single-family dwellings unless a change in use occurs within ten years from the date of passage of the applicable main extension ordinance. The change in use shall refer to any change in the building footprint or additional development of the property on which the single-family dwelling exists or a change in the single-family dwelling such that the use no longer reflects single-family occupancy. 
(4)  When an extension is performed by the city, any single-family dwelling and the property on which the dwelling resides shall not be required to plat, nor shall it be subject to the general development ordinance. If the use of the dwelling or property should change, the property shall be subject to the general development ordinance and other requirements associated with the development process. 
(Ord. No. 2089-2-96, § II, 2-5-96; Ord. No. 2240-7-97, § I, 7-21-97)  
Sec. 16-204. - Connection charges. 
(a)  General. The city shall require all buildings of residential, commercial or heavy industrial occupancy to secure services from the city for water and sewer. Solid waste disposal shall be provided by the approved franchisee. Billing for solid waste collection shall be included on the monthly water and sewer billing statement, if applicable. 
(1)  Application to secure services for water, sewer and solid waste must be in accordance with the general policies of the city. 
(2)  Connection charges do not include required deposits, local impact fees or other charges which are not associated with the direct connection or accounting procedures of the connection. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Administration charge shall mean cost incurred to establish the account for water, sewer, and solid waste. The term "cost" also includes cost for processing and handling of the meter. 
Applicant responsibility shall mean cost of materials and/or labor solely assumed by the applicant. 
Construction estimate shall mean an estimate prepared by the department of public services to provide the necessary materials, labor and inspections to install a service line from a main to a point approved as the point of termination of the city's responsibility. The distance shall not exceed 100 linear feet unless otherwise approved by the public services director or designated representative. The estimate shall include associated administrative and engineering charges. 
Labor cost shall mean cost incurred for the installation of the required meter only. This item does not include the cost for tapping and/or the service line from the main to the approved meter location. This item, however, includes accessory parts, gaskets and similar items. 
Meter cost shall mean cost incurred for the purchase of the required water meter, five-eighths inch through two inches. 
Sewer service connection shall mean connection of a private building service to the city wastewater system. 
Solid waste service shall mean refuse service to all established or future residential, commercial or heavy industrial occupants by the current approved franchisee. 
Water service connection shall mean connection of a private building service to the city water system. 
(c)  Tapping of mains. Mains within the city may be tapped to secure service by the following methods: 
(1)  Taps may be performed for any service requirement by the applicant upon approval by the department of public services and the community development department; or 
(2)  For service requirements, if requested, five-eighths inch through two inches, the city may prepare a construction estimate to accomplish the tap and service line installation; however, the service line extension shall not exceed 100 feet. The director of public services or designated representative may waive the 100-foot requirement as deemed necessary. 
(d)  Amount of charges. The rates, fees and charges which may be imposed under this section are on file in the office of the city secretary. 
(e)  Construction estimate. If requested, the total cost of materials, labor, administration and engineering charges to extend service shall be estimated and presented to the applicant. No work shall be performed until the required fees are collected. 
(Code 1990, § 2-4-4)  
Sec. 16-205. - Liability for materials. 
Each property owner or subdivider shall furnish materials and shall install all water service lines and sanitary sewer laterals from the mains to the structures at his own cost and expense to meet the standard details and specifications and the approval of the city. 
(Code 1990, § 2-4-6; Ord. No. 2218-5-97, § I, 5-5-97)  
Sec. 16-206. - Relocation of utility lines or structures. 
(a)  All utilities who receive written notification from the city to relocate certain lines or structures necessitated because of public improvements shall proceed with relocation or restructuring of such utilities with promptness and shall use reasonable diligence in the pursuit of the completion of the relocation of such utilities or structures. 
(b)  Any request for reimbursement by a public utility for relocation or restructuring of lines or structures shall be directed to the city and shall be itemized and shall show specific charges for each type and quality of material used with the per quantity charge related thereto, and also for the type and nature of the labor used and the hourly charges therefor. If such utility submits a statement for reimbursement which does not comply with the provisions of this section, such statement shall be returned to the utility and no payment shall be made until such time as the itemized statement required herein is provided by the utility, such information and statement to be provided at no cost or expense to the city nor require any inspection of records or other obligation upon any city employee, but such statement shall clearly reflect the material and labors charged for and the amounts relating thereto as set forth herein. 
(Code 1990, § 2-4-7)  
Sec. 16-207. - Capital recovery fee. 
(a)  Definitions. Living Unit Equivalent (LUE) is defined herein as a measure of equivalent system capacity based on meter size to serve a single-family residential water or sewer service customer. The single-family residential meter shall be defined as one LUE. All LUE's determination for residential or nonresidential users shall be based upon the meter use required, as defined in Exhibit A of section 2-201. 
(b)  Continuation. A capital recovery fee for water and wastewater is hereby continued per living unit equivalents for all property served by the city with such utility services in the sums stated in Exhibit A of section 2-201. 
(c)  Effective date for fees. The effective date for the amending of water and wastewater impact fees shall be November 1, 2018. Capital recovery fees shall be assessed in accordance with the schedule of capital recovery fees per LUE as established in Exhibit "A" of section 2-201. 
(d)  Extraordinary situations. In the event an extraordinary structure or use is proposed, in which the meter equivalence method is not appropriate, the city manager or his designee shall determine the appropriate fee for such situation based on specific information provided and generally accepted engineering practices. 
(e)  Collection of fees. The fees established herein shall be collected at the time of issuance of a building permit except when a permit is issued for a shell building, in which case the fees shall be collected at the time the interior finish permit is issued. If a permit is requested for plumbing unrelated to building finishout, then the fee shall be paid at the time of issuance of the plumbing permit. 
(f)  When fee not required. No such fees shall be paid where a structure is being replaced or remodeled where the replacement construction is composed of the same number of LUE's or meter size. 
(g)  Reimbursement. If a portion of a main is designated as a capital recovery project and is constructed by others, they would, with prior approval of the city, be reimbursed the construction cost of that portion of the main from the capital recovery project impact fees. 
(h)  Deposit of funds. All water capital recovery fees generated by this section shall be deposited in the water capital recovery fee account of the water and sewer fund and all fees and interest accrued in the account shall be used to finance water capital improvement projects. All wastewater capital recovery fees generated by this section shall be deposited in the wastewater capital recovery fee account of the water and sewer fund and all fees and interest accrued in such account shall be used to finance wastewater capital improvement projects. 
(i)  Appeals. The city council or a board designated by the city council shall serve as an appeal board in the event one affected by this section wishes to file an appeal from its application. All expenses incurred in connection with such appeal shall be paid by the appellant. Written notice of appeal shall be given within ten days from the date of action or decision by the city staff, and a decision shall be made by the appeal board within 30 days thereafter, which decision shall be final. 
(j)  Periodic review. This section and its administration shall be reviewed by the city council no less frequently than every five years. 
(k)  Waiver of fees. The city council may waive the collection of such fees for construction performed by the tax supported entities and for persons in owner occupied single-family dwelling units who meet community development block grant property and income requirements. 
(l)  Installment payments. The property owner of an existing single family structure located in a single family zoned district to which water and/or sewer service is not currently provided by the city may request to pay water and/or sewer capital recovery fees in installment payments in lieu of a one-time lump sum. 
(1)  Owners of property located in commercial, multifamily or any other non-single family zoned property are not eligible for installment payment agreements. 
(2)  An eligible property owner may request installment payments from the community development department, using the application form provided by the city. The completed form must include a copy of the property's most recent receipt or statement from one of the taxing entities, which include Denton County, Lewisville Independent School District or the City of Lewisville. 
(3)  Prior to application for installment payments, all associated fees, including, but not limited to, permit fees, deposit fees, water fees, administration fees, monthly usage fees and monthly garbage service fees, must be paid in full. Payment of these fees is in addition to payment of the capital recovery fee. 
(4)  The term of the installment payment agreement may be for 12, 24, 36, 48, or 60 months, whichever is chosen by the property owner. 
(5)  The principal amount shall be established based upon the capital recovery fee for the year in which the installment payment agreement is signed. The capital recovery fee shall be adjusted annually on January 1 of each year and is calculated every year to establish the annual requirements. 
(6)  Interest will be included in the installment payments. 
(7)  The installment payment amount shall be included on the water (usage) bill. Accordingly, the water bill will include the capital recovery fee installment amount, actual water service fee and garbage fee. Failure to pay the installment amount in addition the monthly water and garbage fees will result in termination of service. 
(8)  If the property is sold, transferred, or undergoes any transition in which new ownership occurs, the balance of the installment payment agreement is required to be paid in full prior to reconnection of service. 
(9)  If the property is rented/leased and the renter/lessee agrees to make the installment payments, the renter/lessee and the property owner must apply for the installment payment agreement. Although both the renter/lessee and the property owner apply for the installment payments, the property owner is ultimately responsible for the payment of any unpaid fees associated with the agreement. If the renter/lessee changes during the term of the agreement, a new deposit and agreement shall be required to continue the installment payments. It is the responsibility of the property owner to ensure that a new agreement is signed by the new renter/lessee and returned to the city. 
(Code 1990, § 2-4-8; Ord. No. 1513-1-90, §§ II—XI, 1-22-90; Ord. No. 1871-1-94, §§ II—XII, 1-17-94; Ord. No. 2391-11-98, § 1(a), 11-2-98; Ord. No. 2394-11-98, § 1, 10-19-98; Ord. No. 2768-01-2002, § 1, 12-10-01; Ord. No. 3431-04-2007, § 1, 4-2-07; Ord. No. 3797-09-2010 , § 3, 9-13-10; Ord. No. 3929-04-2012 , § 1, 3-5-12; 0075-18-ORD , § 3, 10-15-18)  
Secs. 16-208—16-230. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - WATER REGULATIONS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Requirements for improvements on land served by substandard public improvements, § 6-436 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 16-231. - Unlawful acts. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to do, commit or assist in committing any of the following things or acts: 
(1)  To open or close any fire hydrant, meter box cover or stop cock connected with the water system, or lift or remove the covers of any gate valves or shutoffs thereof, without the permission of the director of public services, except in case of fire, and then under the direction of officers of the fire department. 
(2)  To interfere with, destroy, deface, injure or wantonly force open any gate or door, or in any way whatsoever destroy, injure or deface any part of any engine house, reservoir, stand pipe, elevated tank, building, or appurtenances, fences, trees, shrubs or fixtures or property appertaining to the water system. 
(3)  To go upon or ascend the stairway or steps, on any elevated water storage tank or stand pipe of the water system, except by permission of the director of public services. 
(4)  To resort to any fraudulent device or arrangement for the purpose of procuring water for himself or others from private connections on premises contrary to the provisions of this article. 
(5)  To place upon or about any fire hydrant, gate, valve or curb cock connected with the water system any object, material, debris or structure of any kind, or to interfere in any manner whatsoever with any of the water system, or to turn on the water after service has been discontinued. 
(6)  To make or permit to be made any connections with the main or service pipes of the water system or to turn on or use the water of the system without first obtaining a permit therefor. 
(7)  To remove any water meter or water meter lid that has been placed by the city or allowable procedure described herein, or to in any manner change, interfere with or tamper with any water meter or water meter lid; providing that the provisions of this section shall not apply to the employees of the city or to other allowable state-licensed plumbers when acting in their official capacity. 
(8)  To have in one's possession a key or master key that will unlock water meter lids. This subsection does not apply to city officials or employees, or to state-licensed plumbers for the purpose of installing an original meter as described herein. 
(9)  To install city water meters at the original time of connection for new structures, except for city employees under the direct authorization of the director of the department of public services, or as permitted and specifically directed by a state-licensed plumber. 
(Code 1990, § 2-2-2; Ord. No. 2218-5-97, § I, 5-5-97)  
Sec. 16-232. - Reserved.  
Sec. 16-233. - Report of leaks. 
It shall be the duty of all employees of the city, including officers and members of the police force to report to the director of public services, upon blanks furnished for that purpose, any leaks or unnecessary waste of water that may come to their attention, also any violations of this article. 
(Code 1990, § 2-2-5)  
Sec. 16-234. - Meters generally. 
(a)  All meters belonging to the water system shall be set by the employees of the city or by state-licensed plumbers or by state-licensed irrigators as it strictly relates to the permitted and allowable meter set for new structures only. If the meter becomes inoperative and fails to register, the consumer will be charged at the average daily consumption as shown by the meter when in order. All water that passes through the meter shall be charged for, whether used or not. 
(b)  If a meter is installed at an address other than the address on the corresponding meter account, an administration fee will be charged for reassignment of the meter billing in the city records. This fee is set out in section 2-201 and shall be due with the next water billing. 
(Code 1990, § 2-2-6; Ord. No. 2129-8-96, § 1, 8-5-96; Ord. No. 2218-5-97, § I, 5-5-97; Ord. No. 3797-09-2010 , § 4, 9-13-10)  
Sec. 16-235. - Separate meters required. 
Each consumer of water must have a separate water connection. Additionally, there must be a minimum of one water meter per lot in all zoning categories. Service by one water meter across separate lots shall not be allowed. 
(Code 1990, § 2-2-7; Ord. No. 2218-5-97, § I, 5-5-97)  
Sec. 16-236. - Private lines outside city limits. 
(a)  Private lines. The maintenance and inspection of all private lines (customer lines) extending from the city water meter shall be the responsibility of the property owner. The private line shall include the approved backflow device, if required. 
(b)  Inspection. Each installation of private water lines shall be inspected by the director of public services or his authorized agent and meet the specifications laid down by the city. The owners of the future lines in consideration of permission to tie in to the city lines must agree in writing to give the city the right to determine the number of connections that may be made to the private line by others without city connections who live or will live in reasonable proximity to the private line. The purpose of this section is to cut down frequency and difficulty of maintenance work on the lines and to prevent numerous tie-ins of private lines to city lines with the consequent waste of time, labor and money. 
(Code 1990, § 2-2-8; Ord. No. 2218-5-97, § I, 5-5-97)  
Sec. 16-237. - Repair of water lines. 
In the interest of water conservation, if at any time water lines and connections from the meter loop connection into the residence, house, barn, business, yard or similar places become rusted out, broken or in general deteriorated, it shall be the duty of the owner of the premises to place his lines in a good and serviceable condition. The replaced and repaired lines must meet specifications laid down by the city for original installations. 
(Code 1990, § 2-2-9)  
Sec. 16-238. - Meter deposit. 
(a)  The deposit for services furnished by the city water system is set out in section 2-201. The deposit shall be collected by the city prior to the city's rendering such services for all nonresidential accounts. For residential accounts, the deposit shall be collected by the city prior to the city's rendering such services; provided, however, the deposit may be collected in full by the city by the due date of the customer's first monthly billing if requested by the customer and approved by the city manager or his designee. 
(b)  If such deposits are insufficient to pay an average monthly bill, or if experience has proved that a customer does not pay water bills promptly, and as due, the city manager or his designee may require the meter deposit to be in any sum deemed necessary to protect the city. 
(c)  Such meter deposit may be applied to the payment of any water, sewer, or garbage charge overdue to the city. Any unused portion of the deposit shall be refunded to the customer at any time service is discontinued. 
(Code 1990, § 2-2-10; Ord. No. 2245-8-97, § 1, 8-4-97)  
Sec. 16-239. - Construction meters and deposit. 
If a user of water service desires connection to a fire hydrant outlet for construction usage, there shall be imposed a charge for the temporary construction meter. Such user shall also pay a water deposit and regular water rates for service rendered. 
(Code 1990, § 2-2-10.5; Ord. No. 2218-5-97, § I, 5-5-97)  
Sec. 16-240. - Nonfranchise sale of water. 
(a)  No person located or doing business in the city shall distribute or sell water in any form or container to any person unless such water shall first have been distributed and sold by the city, or its franchisee. 
(b)  No person located or doing business in the city shall sell water indirectly or directly in any form or container to any person in the city. 
(c)  Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to prevent the personal consumption of water by the producer thereof or the sale of ice, soft drinks or bottled water, if the same has been duly approved by the water quality board, and complies with the requirements of the state and the city health departments. 
(d)  This section shall not be applicable to anyone unless and until the expiration of 30 days from the first date that a water tap shall become available to the individual or corporation involved. 
(e)  No person shall deposit or put into the sanitary sewer system of the city any effluent whatsoever unless the same be metered by sewage meter approved by the city and installed and maintained at the sole expense of such individual or corporation so depositing the effluent. 
(f)  This section shall not be construed to apply to or require any action by any person selling or distributing water on the effective date hereof; however, this section shall apply in full force and effect to any person selling or distributing water after the effective date hereof. 
(Code 1990, § 2-2-12)  
Sec. 16-241. - Restricted access to areas surrounding raw water intake structures. 
(a)  Definitions. In this section, "raw water intake structure" means a steel or concrete pier-type structure which supports the pumps, motors and electrical equipment that is necessary to pump water from a water source to another location. 
(b)  Restrictions. 
(1)  A restricted zone of 550 feet radius from the raw water intake structure and associated works shall be established. 
(2)  All recreational activities shall be prohibited in this area. No boat launching ramps, marinas, docks or floating fishing piers which are accessible by the public may be located within 1,000 feet of the raw water intake structure. 
(3)  Any person found within the restricted zone without proper authorization from the structure owner shall be found in violation of this section and shall be subject to legal action as prescribed by law. 
(4)  The restricted zone shall be clearly designated with signs defining restrictions. The signs shall be maintained in plain view of the public and shall be visible from outside the restricted area. 
(5)  Special buoys may be required as deemed necessary by the city director of public services and the manager of the water source. 
(c)  Appendices. An appendix to Ordinance No. 2246-8-97 shall be made for each raw water intake structure to be located within the jurisdiction of the city. This appendix shall detail the physical location of the structure in order to determine the restricted zone. 
(d)  Enforcement. Strict enforcement of the provisions of this section will be implemented by the city police department. 
(e)  Penalty. 
(1)  Any person who shall willfully or negligently violate any provision of this section shall, and upon conviction, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00. 
(2)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall become liable to the owner for any expense, loss, or damage occasioned by the owner by reason of such violation. 
(Ord. No. 2246-8-97, §§ II—VI, 8-4-97) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 2246-8-97, adopted August 4, 1997, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, codification of §§ II—VI of said ordinance as § 16-241 was at the discretion of the editor.  
Secs. 16-242—16-250. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - WATER CONSERVATION AND WATER MANAGEMENT PLAN[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 4059-04-2014 , §§ 1, 2, adopted April 7, 2014, repealed and reenacted division 2 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, division 2 pertained to the water shortage rationing program, and derived from Ord. No. 2633-3-2001, § 2, adopted March 9, 2001; Ord. No. 2847-09-2002, §§ 1, 2, adopted August 9, 2002. 
 
Sec. 16-251. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this section is to establish the city's policy and procedures to reduce water consumption, specifically for lawn and landscape irrigation. Water conservation measures are intended to reduce loss and waste of water, improve the efficiency in the use of water and to protect water as a valuable resource on a continuous basis and most essentially in the event of shortages or delivery limitations in the city's water supply. This section applies to: 
(1)  All persons and premises within the city using water from the water system. 
(2)  All retail service customers outside the city using water from the water system to the extent provided by section 16-259. 
(3)  All wholesale service customers outside the city to the extent provided by section 16-259. 
(Ord. No. 4059-04-2014 , § 2, 4-7-14; 0120-19-ORD , § 2, 5-6-19)  
Sec. 16-252. - Emergency water management plan. 
The emergency water management plan of the city shall be as follows: 
(1)  Stage 1: Water Watch—Mandatory Restrictions: 
a.  Criteria. 
1.  Conservation. Measures to ensure that the City of Lewisville can continue to deliver safe, dependable drinking water to retail and wholesale customers. The target for this first stage is to achieve a five percent reduction in total gallons per capita per day (GPCD). 
2.  Effective period. Mandatory year-round restrictions shall be in place to reduce water consumption for lawn and landscape irrigation, improve water efficiency and control for the waste and loss of water. 
i.  Single-family residential landscape watering shall follow the schedule: 
Even: Those residential addresses that are evenly numbered (0, 2, 4, 6, 8), or those customers with no street address, may irrigate landscaped areas with hose-end sprinklers or automatic irrigation systems no more than twice per week on Tuesday and Saturdays. May 1st through September 30th of each year, outdoor irrigating is permitted only between the designated hours of 6:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m. 
Odd: Those residential addresses that are oddly numbered (1, 3, 5, 7, 9) may irrigate landscaped areas with hose-end sprinklers or automatic irrigation systems no more than twice per week on Wednesday and Sundays. May 1st through September 30th of each year outdoor irrigating is permitted only between the designated hours of 6:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m. 
ii.  Commercial landscape, including multi-family residential shall follow the schedule: 
Commercial water customers may water on Monday and Thursdays. May 1st through September 30 of each year outdoor irrigating is permitted only between the designated hours of 6:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m. 
iii.  No landscape watering with hose-end sprinklers or automatic irrigation systems will be allowed on Fridays. 
iv.  Drip irrigation, soaker hoses and hand-watering are allowed on any day between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. 
v.  Modifications of restrictions listed may be necessary to address water system irregularities and system delivery issues as determined by the plan administrator. 
(2)  Stage 2: Water Emergency—Mandatory Restrictions: 
a.  Triggering criteria (if one or more occurs): 
1.  Supply. 
i.  Total raw water supply in Dallas Water Utilities connected reservoirs exceeds 50 percent depletion. 
ii.  Dallas Water Utilities implements conservation measures and requests wholesale customers to implement similar measures. The target for this stage plan is to achieve a 15 percent reduction in total gallons per capita per day (GPCD). 
2.  Distribution. Failure of Stage 1 restrictions to reduce usage below supply capacity. 
3.  Other. Any unanticipated situations that limit distribution of water as determined by the director of public services. 
i.  Short-term or long-term equipment failure or failure to maintain 20 psi pressure at up to 500 service locations or up to ten fire hydrants in localized areas. 
ii.  Short-term deficiencies within a gridded pressure zone. 
b.  Actions available (implemented in total or applied as necessary): 
1.  Mayor, mayor pro tem, city manager, or city manager's designee, as administrator of the emergency water management plan, announces the beginning of Stage 2. 
2.  City staff completes projects to resolve supply or distribution problems. 
3.  Restricted water uses may include the following: 
i.  Hosing off of paved areas, buildings, or windows. 
ii.  Serving of water in restaurants unless requested by the customer. 
iii.  Swimming pool draining followed by refilling. 
iv.  Washing or rinsing of vehicles by hose. 
v.  Water use that allows runoff or other water waste. 
4.  Commercial car washing is prohibited between the hours of 2:00 p.m. and 6:00 p.m. each day. 
5.  Single-family residential landscape watering is allowed only during the designated hours of 6:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m. following the odd or even schedule-those residential addresses that are evenly numbered (0, 2, 4, 6, 8) may water on Tuesday; odd numbered (1, 3, 5, 7, 9) may water only on Wednesday. Drip irrigation, soaker hoses and hand-watering are allowed only on the designated landscape watering days. 
6.  Commercial water customers, including multi-family residential may water landscaping only on Thursdays between the designated hours of 6:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m. 
7.  No landscape watering will be allowed on Monday, Friday, Saturday or Sundays. 
8.  Modifications of restrictions listed may be necessary to address water system irregularities and system delivery issues as determined by the plan administrator. 
9.  All commercial water users may be required to reduce water consumption by a percentage. 
10.  All rates for retail residential water usage in excess of 6,000 gallons per month may be temporarily increased by a percentage. 
11.  Exceptions: 
i.  Foundations may be watered with a soaker or hand-held hose on the same days as landscape watering. 
ii.  Golf courses using potable water or treated municipal wastewater must adhere to the following schedule: 
A.  Greens and tee boxes may be watered only on Monday and Thursdays between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m. 
B.  Fairways may be watered only on Thursdays between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m. 
iii.  Nurseries may water plant stock only between the designated hours of 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. 
iv.  Modifications of actions listed may be necessary to address water system irregularities and system delivery issues as determined by the plan administrator. 
v.  New homes and new businesses will receive a 30-day exemption to water new landscape with the initial certificate of occupancy. 
(3)  Stage 3: Water Crisis—Mandatory Restrictions: 
a.  Triggering criteria (if one or more occurs): 
1.  Supply. 
i.  Total raw water supply in Dallas Water Utilities connected reservoirs exceeds 65 percent depletion. 
ii.  Dallas Water Utilities implements conservation measures and requests wholesale customers to implement similar measures. The target for this third stage of the plan is to achieve a 20 percent reduction in total gallons per capita per day (GPCD). 
2.  Distribution. Failure of Stage 2 restrictions to reduce usage below supply capacity. 
3.  Other. Any unanticipated situations that severely limit distribution of water as determined by the director of public services. 
i.  Short-term or long-term equipment failure or failure to maintain 20 psi pressure at up to 500 service locations or up to ten fire hydrants in localized areas. 
ii.  Short-term deficiencies within a gridded pressure zone. 
b.  Actions available (applied locally or to all customers as necessary): 
1.  Mayor, mayor pro tem, city manager, or city manager's designee, as administrator of the emergency water management plan, announces the beginning of Stage 3. 
2.  All washing of vehicles is prohibited except at commercial car washes on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday during normal business hours. 
3.  All commercial water users may be required to reduce water consumption by a percentage determined by the director of public services. 
4.  All commercial and residential landscape watering is prohibited. 
5.  Exceptions: 
i.  Nurseries may water plant stock between the hours of 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. only on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday. 
ii.  Golf courses may water greens and tee boxes between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. only on Monday, and Thursdays. Fairway watering is prohibited. 
6.  All rates for retail residential water usage in excess of 6,000 gallons per month may be temporarily increased by a percentage. 
If situations arise which are not outlined in Stages 1 through 3, the mayor, mayor pro tem, city manager, or city manager's designee, as administrator of the emergency water management plan, shall establish requirements on a case-by-case basis. 
(Ord. No. 4059-04-2014 , § 2, 4-7-14; Ord. No. 4073-05-2014 , § 1, 5-19-14; 0120-19-ORD , § 2, 5-6-19)  
Sec. 16-253. - Authority generally. 
The mayor, mayor pro tem, city manager, or his designee, shall be administrator of the emergency water management plan. The administrator is authorized to implement measures prescribed in the plan and ensure enforcement of such measures. The administrator shall not promulgate regulations that are in conflict with this section or state or federal laws in the enforcement of the plan. All city employees shall assist as needed in the notification and enforcement of the plan. The neighborhood and inspection services, public services and police departments shall be authorized to enforce penalties upon violation. 
(Ord. No. 4059-04-2014 , § 2, 4-7-14; 0120-19-ORD , § 2, 5-6-19)  
Sec. 16-254. - Authority under other laws. 
Nothing under this section shall be construed to limit the authority of the administrator of the plan to seek emergency relief under the provisions of any state or federal disaster relief act. 
(Ord. No. 4059-04-2014 , § 2, 4-7-14; 0120-19-ORD , § 2, 5-6-19)  
Sec. 16-255. - Implementation of an emergency. 
The director of public services shall advise the administrator of the plan when the conditions of a water emergency exist. The administrator shall order the appropriate stage of emergency as detailed in the plan be implemented. To be effective immediately, the order shall be made by public media. 
(Ord. No. 4059-04-2014 , § 2, 4-7-14; 0120-19-ORD , § 2, 5-6-19)  
Sec. 16-256. - Duration of the order; change and extension. 
Upon recommendation of the director of public services, the administrator may upgrade or downgrade the stage of emergency when the conditions triggering the emergency stage change. Any change in the status of the order shall be made in the same manner prescribed in section 16-255 for implementing orders. 
The administrator may terminate the order in the manner prescribed in section 16-255 when the director of public services determines that the conditions creating the emergency no longer exist. 
(Ord. No. 4059-04-2014 , § 2, 4-7-14; 0120-19-ORD , § 2, 5-6-19)  
Sec. 16-257. - Offenses and penalties. 
A person commits an offense if he or she knowingly makes, causes, or permits a use of water contrary to the measures implemented. Any person who violates or fails to comply with any provision of the plan shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof in the municipal court of the city, shall be subject to a fine of not more than $2,000.00 for each offense. Each day such offense is continued shall constitute a new and separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 4059-04-2014 , § 2, 4-7-14; 0120-19-ORD , § 2, 5-6-19)  
Sec. 16-258. - Variances—Conditions for granting and revoking. 
During times the plan is operative, the administrator may grant variances in special cases after evaluation of hardship, need, or customer efforts to conserve water. 
The administrator may grant variances only when the applicant provides a written request to the administrator. The applicant must demonstrate extreme hardship or need relating to his health, safety or welfare to be granted a variance. Granting of the variance shall not cause an immediate significant reduction in the city's water supply nor shall it adversely affect the health, safety or welfare of other persons. The administrator may revoke a variance when it is determined that the conditions warranting the variance are no longer being met; the terms of the compliance agreement have been or are being violated; or the health, safety or welfare of other persons requires revocation. 
(Ord. No. 4059-04-2014 , § 2, 4-7-14; Ord. No. 4073-05-2014 , § 1, 5-19-14; 0120-19-ORD , § 2, 5-6-19)  
Sec. 16-259. - Wholesale service to customers outside city. 
The administrator of the plan shall advise retail and wholesale customers receiving retail/wholesale water service from the city of actions taken under the emergency water management plan. 
The administrator may restrict service to retail and wholesale customers outside the city as permitted under contract and in accordance with state law. 
(Ord. No. 4059-04-2014 , § 2, 4-7-14; 0120-19-ORD , § 2, 5-6-19)  
Secs. 16-260—16-280. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - UTILITY FEES, CHARGES, RATES AND BILLING PROCEDURE  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 16-281. - Rates, etc., on file. 
The utility rates, fees, deposits and other charges are set out in section 2-201.  
Secs. 16-282—16-290. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - RATE DETERMINATION PROCEDURE 
 
Sec. 16-291. - Effect of division. 
The rules and regulations contained in this division shall be in full force and effect as between the city and the various utility companies operating within the city by virtue of franchise agreements with the city, hereinafter referred to as the "utility." 
(Code 1990, § 2-1-1(A))  
Sec. 16-292. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Allocations shall mean for all utilities, the division of plant revenues, expenses, taxes and reserves between cities or between cities and unincorporated areas, where such items are used for providing utility service for more than one city or for a city and unincorporated areas. Examples of items subject to allocation include general office buildings, general administrative expenses, and income taxes. 
Public utility shall mean any person engaged in regularly supplying the public within the corporate limits with some commodity or service which is of special consequence and need, such as the electricity, gas, transportation and telephone service. 
(Code 1990, § 2-1-1(B)) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 16-293. - Exception. 
The provisions of this division shall not apply to the telephone communication utility operating within the city. 
(Code 1990, § 2-1-1(J))  
Sec. 16-294. - Determination of rates. 
(a)  Fair value. Utility rates shall be based on the fair value of property used and useful in providing service to the inhabitants of the city. "Fair value" shall be a reasonable balance between original adjustment for both age and condition. 
(b)  Balance between original, replacement costs. As may be determined by the city, "reasonable balance" shall mean not less than 60 percent nor more than 75 percent weighting of original costs less depreciation and not less than 25 percent nor more than 40 percent weighting of replacement or trended costs less adjustment for both age and condition. In the city's determination of reasonable balance, it may consider inflation, deflation, quality of service being provided, growth rate of service area, capital structure and need for the utility to attract new capital. 
(c)  Deduction. In arriving at fair value rate base, the city may deduct any capital not supplied by investors. By way of example, the city may deduct contributions in aid of construction, deferred liabilities such as deferred income taxes and investment tax credit allowed by law, and customer deposits. 
(d)  Rate base. When requesting a change in rates the utility shall specify and identify for rate base purposes, the following items and the manner in which they were determined: 
(1)  Construction work in progress. 
(2)  Plant held for future use. 
(3)  Materials and supplies. 
(4)  Working capital. 
The city may, in consideration of local circumstances, require or permit, by specific action, treatment of the four items enumerated above in any manner it considers appropriate and reasonable. The city may include or exclude other items from the rate base for reasonable cause. 
(Code 1990, § 2-1-1(C))  
Sec. 16-295. - Reporting requirements. 
(a)  Information to be filed. The utility shall file annually with the city secretary a complete balance sheet and operating statement of the utility and a statement of the total number of customers by classes served within the city and within the service territory covered by the operating statement. Such statements shall cover the fiscal year of the utility unless some other fiscal period shall be approved by the city; and shall be filed within 120 days after the close of such period. In addition, the utility shall file: 
(1)  A cost of service report and operating statement for the city or such other service area appropriate for establishing local rates. 
(2)  Copies of statistical and operating reports filed with other regulatory agencies such as the Federal Communications Commission, Federal Power Commission, Public Utility Commission of Texas, or the Texas Railroad Commission. 
(3)  A copy of annual and interim reports prepared for release to existing and prospective investors. 
(4)  Such other reports or special information as may reasonably be required by the city for supervision of the utility and for the regulation of local rates and service. 
(b)  Change in rates. In connection with consideration of a change in basic rates, the utility shall furnish to the city such information as is reasonably required for the city to evaluate and determine the rate base, operating income and expenses, and a fair rate of return, the burden of proof being with the utility. In addition, the utility may file, and shall file if requested by the city, schedules of present and proposed rates, analysis of customer bills or such other information necessary for the verification of revenue effect of proposed rates, schedules of rates in other jurisdictions, and such other information the city may reasonably request for a full and fair consideration of a change in rates or service. If appropriate for a fair determination of local rates, the city may consider a service area beyond its city limits and may require information thereof from the utility. 
(c)  Test year. Any requests by the utility for rate increase shall use as their "test year," the most recent 12 months for which operating data for the utility are available, and shall commence with a calendar quarter. 
(d)  Certification. The city hereby requires that information furnished by the utility to the city be supplied under oath by an appropriate official of the utility as to correctness, authenticity and adherence to accepted practices or recognized standards. 
(Code 1990, § 2-1-1(D))  
Sec. 16-296. - Expenses. 
(a)  All reasonable and necessary expenses of operating the utility shall be allowed in the determination of net operating revenue. Expenses included in annual reports or other reports to the city shall be determined from and supported by actual expenses recorded on the utility's books. When filing for a rate increase, the utility shall show actual revenue and expenses recorded on books and adjustments necessary in order to properly present net operating revenue for the period under review. Depreciation expense shall be based upon original cost and not upon the measures of value of assets. 
(b)  The city may require an annual reporting from each utility company of all its expenditures for business gifts and entertainment, and institutional, consumption-inducing and other advertising or public relations expenses. The city shall not allow as costs or expenses for rate-making purposes any of these expenditures which the city determines not to be in the public interest. The cost of legislative-advocacy expenses shall not in any case be allowed as costs or expenses for rate-making purposes. Reasonable charitable or civic contributions may be allowed not to exceed the amount approved by the city. 
(Code 1990, § 2-1-1(E))  
Sec. 16-297. - Rate of return. 
The utility shall be entitled to a fair return upon the fair value rate base of its property used and useful in providing service to the inhabitants of the city as provided by law. 
(Code 1990, § 2-1-1(F))  
Sec. 16-298. - Procedural rules for rate increase. 
(a)  Application. The utility shall file its application for a general rate increase by delivering such application to the city secretary. Any such application shall include or be accompanied by the following information presented on both a system-wide and an allocated basis for the city only: 
(1)  Summary information: 
a.  A summary of the increase in revenue requirements and the spread of the revenue increase by customer classification. 
b.  A summary of the results of operations for the test year, and the fiscal year ended prior to the end of the test year. 
c.  A summary of the capital structure for the test year and the fiscal year ended prior to the end of the test year. 
d.  Construction expenditures and gross utility plant in service for the test year and the fiscal year ended prior to the end of the test year. 
e.  A summary of changes in financial position for the test year and the fiscal year ended prior to the end of the test year. 
f.  A summary showing the development of all allocation factors used in allocating data for the city. 
(2)  Rate base information: 
a.  A schedule showing the elements of original cost and current cost rate bases. 
b.  A schedule listing proposed adjustments to gross plant in service and accumulated depreciation for the original cost rate base. 
c.  A schedule demonstrating the determination of current cost less allowance for age and condition for the test period. 
d.  A schedule showing proposed adjustments to gross plant in service and the allowance for age and condition for the current cost rate base. 
e.  A schedule showing calculations in weighting used in determining fair value rate base. 
f.  A schedule showing the computation of working capital allowance. 
g.  A detailed schedule showing the development of all allocation factors used in allocating the rate base data to the city. 
(3)  Test year income statements: 
a.  A test year income statement, with any proposed adjustments. 
b.  A schedule showing the detail of all proposed adjustments. 
c.  A schedule showing the incremental taxes and other expenses on gross revenues and the computation of an incremental gross revenue conversion factor. 
d.  A detailed schedule showing the development of all allocation factors used in allocating revenues and expenses to the city. 
(4)  Cost of capital information: 
a.  A schedule summarizing the elements in the capital structure at the end of the test year. 
b.  A schedule showing the detail of long-term and short-term debt at the end of the test year and their total cost. 
c.  A schedule showing the detail of preferred stock at the end of the test year and their total cost. 
d.  A schedule summarizing conclusions of the required return on book common equity as of the end of the test year. 
e.  A statement of the fair rate of return being requested. 
(5)  Projections and forecasts: 
a.  A projected income statement for the projected year compared with actual test year results, at present rates and proposed rates. 
b.  A projected balance sheet for the projected year compared to the test year, at present rates and proposed rates. 
c.  Projected changes in financial position for the projected year compared with the test year, at present rates and proposed rates. 
d.  Projected annual construction requirements by property classification, for one to three years subsequent to the test year, compared with the test year. 
e.  Important assumptions used in preparing forecasts and projections. 
(6)  Cost of service information: 
a.  Schedule showing rates of return by customer classification at present and proposed rates. 
b.  Schedules showing approach used in allocating plant and expenses to classes of service and defined functions. 
c.  Schedules showing the development of all allocation factors used in the cost of service study. 
d.  A comparison of revenues by customer classification or other classification of revenues for the test year, at present and proposed rate. 
e.  A comparison of revenues by class of service and by rate schedule for the test year, at present and proposed rates. 
f.  A comparison of present and proposed rate schedules at representative rate schedules. 
g.  Typical bill analysis including range of seasonal high and low costs. 
(b)  Expenses of rate cases. The city shall have the right to select and employ rate consultants, engineers, accountants, auditors, attorneys and other personnel to conduct investigations, present evidence, advise the council, and conduct litigation on the establishment of rates, charges or fares; the utility shall reimburse the city for all such personnel costs and all other reasonable and necessary expense incurred; and such rate consultants, engineers, accountants, auditors and attorneys shall be qualified, competent, and of good standing in their professions. 
(c)  Rules of procedure. The city may adopt rules of procedure for public hearings, including extent and nature of presentations, order of proceeding and extent of cross-examination. 
(d)  Records of utility. Copies of requested records shall be promptly provided to any designated representative of the city without cost to the city. 
(e)  Hearings. No general rate increase shall be granted without public hearing at which the utility shall have the burden of proving, through clear and convincing evidence, the necessity for such increase. All hearings may be before the full city council. At the discretion of the city council, in each case, the city council may provide that hearings shall be conducted before a committee of the city council, a hearing examiner who may be an employee of the city, any person designated by the city council to act in such capacity. In the event the full city council does not conduct the hearings, a written report and recommendation from the committee or examiner shall be filed with the city council. In such latter case, the city council need not conduct further hearings, but may act on the basis of such report and recommendation together with any written argument which any citizen, the utility, utility representative, designated city staff member, auditor, attorney or consultant engaged by the city may wish to file within 15 days after filing of such report in response to such report or recommendation. The city, in its discretion may require that a record be made of all public hearings, at the expense of the utility, with a copy to be furnished the city. 
(f)  Evidence. All testimony of such public hearings shall be under oath and all exhibits or documentary evidence introduced at such hearings shall be supported by sworn testimony. For this purpose, oath may be administered by appropriate parties conducting the hearing. 
(g)  Time limitations. The city shall promptly review and take action on each application for a general rate increase within 90 days after its proper filing. Failure to act within such period shall be tantamount to a denial. In the event of such failure to act, the utility may appeal such decision as provided by law. Such 90-day period may be extended through agreement with the utility, or if the city council finds good cause for such extension. Good cause for extension shall include, but not be limited to, complexity or magnitude of the evidence, failure of the utility to promptly proceed, failure of the utility to promptly provide information requested and newly discovered evidence. 
(h)  Appeal. The utility may appeal the city's action as provided by law. An appeal should not be taken until the utility has exhausted its remedies under this division. 
(i)  Standards of service. The city may promulgate reasonable standards of service and requirements for extension of facilities. Failure to substantially comply with such standards, considering the revenues and expenses of the utility, may justify a lower rate of return being granted to the utility. The city's rate ordinance may provide for increases subject to the meeting of such standards or making certain extensions of facilities. 
(Code 1990, § 2-1-1(G))  
Sec. 16-299. - Rate review by city. 
By resolution of the city council, the city may institute a review of the rates of a utility. Notice of any such review shall be given to the utility by sending a copy of such resolution by United States mail to the utility at its home or local office. Within the time specified in such notice the utility should file with the city secretary all information as required in section 16-298 in relation to an application by the utility for a general rate increase. All the provisions of this division dealing with an application for a general rate increase by a utility shall apply to a review of utility rates by the city under this section. 
(Code 1990, § 2-1-1(F))  
Sec. 16-300. - Adjustments for leaks. 
(a)  Authorized. Any user or customer who is billed for a substantial increase in water usage during any one, or if related, two consecutive billing periods due to a hidden water leak, may request and receive an adjustment in the amount billed for water and sewer usage for that month in accordance with the provisions of this section. Any user or customer who is billed for a substantial increase in water usage which affects the three-month winter average provided by section 16-311 in any one billing period due to a leak which has been repaired and documented may request and receive an adjustment in the subsequent sewer amount only, billed pursuant to the sewer usage average in accordance with provisions of this section. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Hidden water leak shall mean any leak of a water pipe, line or other water conveyance equipment caused by deterioration, corrosion, unknown damage, natural forces or other similar cause which is not immediately and reasonably detectable. 
Substantial increase in water usage shall mean an increase in the amount of water metered and billed in excess of 100 percent of a water usage level based upon the average of the two monthly water usage levels billed immediately preceding the discovery of the leak or indeterminable high water usage for which the adjustment is requested at the service location and must additionally meet the test of exceeding 100 percent of the water usage level for the same month in the most immediate three-year historical period. 
(c)  Written request. Any user or customer requesting a water and sewer adjustment pursuant to this section shall make the request in writing to the customer service activity division of the finance department on forms provided for that purpose. A request for an adjustment based on a hidden leak shall state the location and cause of the leak, the date it was discovered, and the date of, and person, making the repair, with attached copies of repair labor or material bills. Repairs shall have been completed within 30 days of the discovery date of the leak to be eligible for an adjustment. All requests shall be submitted within 60 days of the billed date of the monthly bill for which an adjustment is sought. If a user's or customer's three-month winter average provided by section 16-311 is affected by the one-month substantial increase in water usage, the request shall be submitted within 60 days of the billed date of the March monthly bill. 
(d)  Water and sewer adjustment allowed. A request for an adjustment in a monthly bill for water and sewer usage shall be granted if it meets the following conditions: 
(1)  A written request, with all information in conformance as stipulated in this section is filed within the required time; 
(2)  The requested adjustment is for a monthly billing in which there is a substantial increase in water usage resulting from a hidden leak or other indeterminable caused metered water volume increase; and 
(3)  There has not been an adjustment made in the monthly billing for water or sewer usage at the same service location within the prior twelve-month period. 
(e)  Sewer only adjustment allowed. A request for an adjustment in one monthly bill and subsequent bills effected pursuant to section 16-311 for billing sewer usage shall be granted if it meets the following conditions: 
(1)  A written request, with all information in conformance as stipulated in this section is filed within the required time; 
(2)  The requested adjustment is for a substantial increase in water usage for November, December, January, or February resulting from a leak; and 
(3)  There has not been an adjustment made in the monthly billing for water or sewer usage within the prior six-month period. 
(f)  Amount of adjustment. If an adjustment is granted under this section, the customer's or user's account shall be adjusted by billing the customer or user an amount equivalent to the average of the two monthly water usage levels billed immediately preceding the excess usage. 
(g)  Inspection, verification. If a discrepancy appears in a monthly billing, the meter reading personnel of the city finance department shall inspect and verify the meter reading upon request of a customer or user. If the discrepancy is verified or a customer or user requests two or less inspections during a 12-month period, such inspection shall be of no cost to the customer or user; otherwise, the charge for a meter verification fee shall be as set out in section 2-201. 
(h)  Appeals. Any requested variance or disagreement on the part of the user, customer, or city staff pertaining to the administration of section 16-300 should be submitted to the city manager in writing stating the appealing party's position and desired resolution. The city manager will make the final decision and direct city staff accordingly. 
(Code 1990, § 2-1-2.5; Ord. No. 2090-2-96, § 1, 2-5-96; Ord. No. 2633-12-2000, §§ 1, 2, 12-11-00; Ord. No. 3892-09-2011 , § I, 9-19-11)  
Secs. 16-301—16-309. - Reserved.  
Sec. 16-310. - Water rates. 
(a)  Retail water rates: The monthly rates and charges for metered water usage for retail service furnished by the city water works system are set out in section 2-201. 
(b)  Wholesale water rates: The rates and charges for treated water, as, if and when it is received by the wholesale customer city from the City of Lewisville are set out in section 2-201. 
(Ord. No. 1738-11-92, § 2, 11-2-92)  
DIVISION 3. - SEWER 
 
Sec. 16-311. - Sewer rates. 
(a)  Single-family dwelling: Current customers' rates shall be based upon the four-month winter average of monthly water consumption billed in the most recent December, January, February and March for such dwelling and charged pursuant to the fee schedule set out in section 2-201. In the event the winter average prescribed exceeds water consumption billed for any current month, the sewer billing calculation will utilize the lesser current water consumption gallons. 
(b)  Nonsingle-family dwellings. Rates shall be based upon each month's water consumption, and are set out in section 2-201. 
(c)  New customers. All new customers or current customers changing dwellings shall be charged a flat monthly fee as set out in section 2-201 until the winter average can be established at the new dwelling. 
(Code 1990, § 2-1-3(A)—(C); Ord. No. 1848-9-93, § 1, 9-20-93)  
Sec. 16-312. - Landscaping. 
It shall be presumed that each water meter results in waste entering the sanitary sewer system. However, upon satisfactory proof that a water meter is installed and used solely for landscaping or other purposes whereby no water from such meter enters the sanitary sewer system, the city manager or his designee may waive sewer charges. 
(Code 1990, § 2-1-3(D))  
Sec. 16-313. - Sewer only customers.
